(c) Other common names: (i) Square, Dab, Plaice, Diamond or Diamond-back, Tin-plate, Three Corners. ## dactylanthus
 
 <i>n.</i> wood rose

>  Pureora's endangerd <i>dactylanthus</i> population has a rare claim to fame - it is one of the few sites where another endangered endemic species, the short tailed bat, is known to assist with pollination of the plant. .. <i>Dactylanthus</i> is New Zealand's only completely parasitic plant and grows at several sites in Pureora Forest Park. <i>(Jul 2005,Conservation Action,p24</i>)

>  <b>BACON</b> It was a small twig, of reddish wood, with three delicately shaped wooden flowers clustered towards the end. They were hard, beautifully fashioned, securely fastened to the stem. `No, they won't come off,' said Les. `That's dactylanthus; Dactylanthus Taylori. It's a parasite that gets into the roots of various native trees, usually five finger or lancewood.' <i>(1963,In the Sticks,57</i>)

>  &#65279;Ecroyd recently succeeded in germinatingdactylanthus seeds. <i>(Jun 1992,North & South,18</i>)

>  &#65279;Richard Taylor, early missionary and thefirst European to describe dactylanthusand send samples to England, reportedhearing about blue flowers seen inTaranaki, but Ecroyd suspects these mayhave been fungi. <i>(Jun 1992,North & South,18</i>)

>  I notice Mr H. Hill has been collecting a rare plant discovered by him a few years ago, etc. The plant would be Dactylanthus Taylori, order Balanophoreae. <i>(Jan 17, 1908,Colonist (Nelson),2</i>)

>  The method by which Dactylanthus Taylori (as this plant is known scientifically) obtains food from its host, is most curious and interesting. . . <i>(Nov 13, 1926,Evening Post,15</i>)

>  <i>"Wooden flowers," which are the roots of a host plant moulded into these pansy-like shapes by the absorbent action of the Dactylanthus rhyzome as it grows adherent to the host root.</i> <i>(Apr 20, 1937,Evening Post,16</i>) [NOTES: italics correct]

>  .. and Mr Hamilton drew attention to a specimen of an extrememly rare plant - the <i>Dactylanthus taylori</i> - found in the North Island. <i>(Jun 10, 1891,Otago Daily Times,2</i>)

>  We have just seen a collection of plants which is perhaps the rarest ever gather in New Zealand. They are known botanically as <i>Dactylanthus Taylori</i>. The native name is pua reinga. <i>(Jul 5, 1895,Hawke's Bay Herald,2</i>)

>  Excellent specimens of a beautiful and rather rare parasite, known to the botanical world as dactylanthus Taylorii [sic] and colloquially as woodflowers, were found by Mr. H. J. Frost when excavating at a house site in New Plymouth. <i>(Jun 27, 1933,Evening Post,6</i>)

>  In the rural districts [of New Zealand] a formidable body of idiomatic uses is developing and a new language is being coined. This isno more true than it is of the `remote' back-country of Canterbury, where changing vocabulary is already a noticable geographical characteristic. The local idiom is naturally often linked with sheep, wool, and station practice. `Dag', for example, is a word used first to describe a tuft of wool fouled by excrement. The removal of dags from the hind-quarters of sheep is a seasonal operation usually called `crutching.' Used personally, `dag' was earlier a term of some approbation. >  <b>REVANS</b> <i>(1841,Letters,170, 180</i>) [NOTES: 1841 Revans Letters (to Chapman) TS ATB 170,180]

>  <b>DILLON</b> He has very large herds and a large dairy where he makes a great deal of butter and cheese. His dairy is of about 40 cows. <i>(Apr 10, 1844,Letters,40,1954 ed.</i>)

>  <b>MACKIE</b> As it grew we reached the hospitable roof of Geo. McRae who has an extensive sheep run and a large dairy. <i>(Mar 11, 1853,Traveller under Concern,86,1973 ed.</i>)

>  <b>FITTON</b> A dairy is ... a more interesting, and, generally, a more prettily situated homestead than asheep station, which ought not to be placed ... where there is low underwood to catch the fleeces of the sheep <i>(1856,New Zealand (various authors/titles),237</i>)

>  `Herringbone' dairies, developed in New Zealand, are increasing rapidly in number. <i>Ibid./</i> 83 The backing gate is used to bring cows from the yard into the dairy. Its main purpose is to keep stock near the milking area. As each cow is taken in to be milked, another fills up the space it has left and there are no delays in milking. The gate is controlled by the milker, who can bring in the next cows without having to leave those already being milked. <i>(1974,NZ Agriculture,81</i>)

>  <b>MACDONALD</b> There were 7 or 8 of us lads and [c1840s] our chief business [15] was a dairy - but not such a dairy as we have now. <i>(1910,Reminiscences,14</i>)



 
<b>2</b> <i>n.</i> The place on a farm where milk, cream etc, are kept and butter made [1844 See Dillon above.]

>  <b>SEDDON</b> The dairy, a cool building shaded by a pine-tree, stood near the house. On a bench which extended along the interior stood large shallow metal dishes in which the milk was placed. <i>(1968,Seddons, The,14</i>) [NOTES: c1880s Seddon The Seddons (1968) 14]

>  Definition. - A `dairy' is: (a) a milk-house, milk-shop, dairy factory, and any other place wheredairy produce is collected, deposited, treated, separated, prepared, or manufactured, or is sold or offered or exposed for sale; and includes (b) a farm, stockyard, milking-yard, paddock, stable,stall, and any other place where cows from which the milk-supply of a dairy is obtained are depastured or kept. <i>(1902,Settler's Handbook of NZ, The,148</i>) [NOTES: 1898 Dairy Industry Act in 1902 Settler's Handbook of NZ 148]

>  (Appendix iii) `Dairy' means - (a) A milk-house, milk shop, dairy factory, and any other placewhere dairy produce is collected, deposited, treated, separated, prepared, or manufactured, or is sold or offered, or exposed for sale; and includes - (b) Any place where cows from which the milk supply of a dairy is obtained are depastured or kept. <i>(1902,Brett's Colonists Guide</i>) [NOTES: 1898 The Dairy Industry Act in 1902 Brett's Colonists' Guide]

>  <b>KEENE</b> A dairy made from packing cases was attached to the back of the house; and shelves to hold the milk pans were made from split rails. <i>(1967,Tang of The Bush,58</i>)

## Daisy Patch
 
 <i>n.</i> a field on Gallipoli

>  ... the brusquely-interrupted tea and the race over the paddock next to the `Daisy Patch' with one or two of us dropping in the machine-gun fire. <i>(1918,New Zealand At the Front,9</i>) [NOTES: (Anzac: A Reverie)]

>  <b>SHADBOLT</b> There [on 5 May 1915 in the front line] survivors were ordered to cross an exposed strip of ground, frosted with spring daisies, before [the Turk-held hill] Achi Baba - a place long to be cursed as `The daisy patch'. ... The daisies were soon less conspicuous than the blackening blood of dead and dying New Zealanders as more and more were urged across the open ground. ... After the daisy patch, demoralisation and anger was as rampant among New Zealand officers as among men. <i>(1988,Voices of Gallipoli,109</i>)

>  <b>WAITE</b> "You're not going to charge across the daisy patch, are you?" "Of course we are," the Aucklanders replied. <i>(1919,New Zealanders at Gallipoli,125</i>)

>  <b>PUGSLEY</b> Every battalion had its "Daisy Patch". <i>(1984,Gallipoli: the New Zealand Story,197</i>)

>  They went first over broken country, butafter a time came to a level plateaucovered with wild flowers. This was "TheDaisy Patch". There the men began tofall. <i>(Aug 18, 1915,Otago Witness,49</i>)

 <i>adj.</i> . [loose comb. danthonia country, turf, tussock.]

I consider the stunted, ill-natured herbage of the better English grasses is less palatablethan the young, fresh herbage of the second rate species. <i>(1951,Grasslands of NZ,134,1970 ed.</i>)

 <i>n.</i> A native group of tussock-grasses; genus to which many spp. of tussock-grasses belong

## day for/on the king/queen
 
 <i>phr.</i> a day off. [(musterers' et al.)]

>  <b>NEWTON</b> ... he and his dogs have a day off [on a foggy day] - in musterers' parlance - `a day for a king.' <i>(1947,Wayleggo,119</i>)

>  <b>PRESTON</b> The next day being wet, all [mustering] hands stayed in camp - a `Day for the King', but not for the poor cook trying to prepare their meals over an open fire in the rain. <i>(1978,Woolgatherers,96</i>)

>  <b>GRADY</b> As well as superstitions, the whalers of Tory Channel had a few time-honoured habits. One of these was known as `a-day-for-the-Queen'. Its main application seems to have been when a whaler had had a heavy day on the grog and had butterflies in his stomach and head the nextday in the form of a hangover. If, for example, a harpoon-gunner like Trevor Norton was to have`a-day-for-the-Queen', he would be on a kind of half-alert. After a solid day on the booze he might find a nice, quiet bunk on board the Perano mother ship Tuatea, where he could nestle down rather than being on lookout duty up on the hill. <i>(1982,Perano Whalers,140</i>)

 <i>n.</i> a D-shaped iron clip or loop on a saddle serving to carry suspended articles.

## deep sea spotty
 
 <i>n.</i> scarlet parrotfish

>  <b>FISHER</b> A number of Parrotfish (they do not live in schools) were following me around and picking up the broken off crayfish legs. The Banded Parrotfish is the most common in the shallows - it blends in with the seaweed - but deeper down the Sandaggers Parrotfish and the Scarlet Parrotfish, often called the `deep sea spotty', take over. <i>(1977,Angels Wear Black,37</i>)



## deep sinking
 
 <i>n.</i> the mining of deep ground or deep leads.

>  The deep sinking has not realised the sanguine expectations once entertained regarding it. <i>(1862,Otago: Its Goldfields and Resources,18</i>)

>  <b>MUELLER</b> The greatest drawback with beach diggins is, they are so quickly washed out. Unless they find gold in the Ranges, and have deep sinking, there is very little prospect of the diggers now at the Coast remaining long. <i>(Jan 2, 1866,My Dear Bannie,100,1958 ed.</i>)

>  <b>MAY</b> DEEP SINKING: putting down a shaft to tap a deep lead. No absolute figure can be given but `deep ground' usually required shafts if over sixty feet. <i>(1967,West Coast Gold Rushes,526,1962 ed.</i>)

>  The Australian diggers soon found out, that hitherto only the superficial deposits had been worked, and that they had not yet come to the `bottom', where ... the richest treasure was to be expected. They began `deep sinkings', and after having dug to a depth of about 130 feet ... struck a second gold-bed. <i>(1867,New Zealand (Hochstetter),113</i>)

## deep thinker
 
 <i>n.</i> a member of later reinforcements. Contrast debt-dodger. [(WW2)]

>  <b>HENDERSON</b> Puzzled, we hear of `Deep Thinkers'. ## Deepfreeze
 
 <i>n.</i> [The operational name for the original 1955-56 summer pre-IGY US Navy Expedition to the Ross Sea and Antarctica, subsequently applied to later expeditions and, with the establishment of a Deepfreeze Base in Christchurch, applied in NZ to any US Navy or US Science Foundation operations or personnel associated with the Antarctic.]

All this.. would not have been necessaryhad someone in authority had theforesight to issue a directive to theChristchurch and Lyttelton police aboutprocedure in the event of any of thepersonnel of "Operation Deepfreeze"getting into trouble.. in New Zealand.about maintaining shore discipline. <i>(Dec 14, 1955,NZ Truth,15</i>)

## deer track
 
 <i>n.</i> [(deer shooters')]

>  In recent years there seems to have been a tendency to use both track and trail and to differentiate between them. A trail seems to be something narrow and perhaps rather hardto follow - a way marked only by blazes or worn by animals, usually deer. A track seems to be something broader, cut or formed by man. ... A well-known older Club member made this distinction when, on hearing him speak of a deer trail, I asked him what he thought to be the difference between track and trail. I remarked that I thought it a very recent distinction, one not occurring in the Club until about 1957. He disagreed, believing it to be one he had always known. Yet, on looking through The Tramper, I could not find deer trail used until 1944, but deer track occurs from the first number in 1928 onwards, and he himself had used it in 1940. It remains to be seen whether this distinction will become established. In the meantime deer track still seems to be used far more than deer trail. <i>(Sep 1958,Tararua,25</i>) [NOTES: Ruth Mason `Track and Trail']

## deferred payment

## depasturage licence
 
 <i>n.</i> the right, by payment of a fee, to graze stock on specified Crown land; = depasturing licence

>  When the selection [of the N.Z. Company share of the Otago Block] had been made the Crowngrant was to be issued, and there was an understanding that if Colonel Wakefield desired stillmore land he was to have it. This was the origin of what was afterwards known as thedepasturage licences, under which settlers were authorised to run cattle and sheep in the adjoining districts. <i>Ibid.</i> 138-139 Under the original terms, land purchasers were entitled upon payment of an annual license fee of 10s. 6d. to depasture or run sheep and cattle upon such waste lands within the block as remained unappropriated. ... though Captain Cargill was then gazetted Commissioner of Crown Lands for the Otago block only, he received no definite instructions upon the subject of granting the runs. [139] The result was that he merely filed the applications for depasturage licenses as they were presented to him, whilst the applicants were left to pursue their further course as seemed best to them. <i>(1898,Contributions to the Early History of New Zealand,59</i>)

## deposited plan
 
 <i>n.</i> In modern times subdivisions of urban and rural land are defined in terms of a surveyor's plan lodged in the office of the currently appropriate administrative entity (Lands and Survey, DOSLI etc) and known as a <i>deposited plan (DP)</i>. [Jim Cameron writes: Individual properties are <i>lots</i> on such a plan and so described on the title. Eg "[20 perches] more or less being part of section 32 Karori District and being Lot 4 on Deposited Plan 8018..." Note pre-metric NZ use of <i>perch</i> to define area. NSOD describes this use as "more fully, square perch ... now rare exc. hist". Until 1968 perch (never square perch) was standard in legal and popular use to describe the area of sections smaller than a quarter-acre.]

>  <b>McGILL</b> dicken disgust or disbelief or surprised belief, in form of an interjection, largely replaced by `really!' or `really?'; an antipodean contraction of `the dickens' or `what the dickens!', being a euphemism for the devil. - dicken on that! go easy, will you!; eg `You want me to help you lift that dirty big post?  <i>exclam.</i>

[AND 1851.] (Collect. pl. or pl. regarded as a sg., the diggings.)]

## diversion
 
 <i>n.</i> n. in criminal procedure, a system for giving a chance for a first- time criminal defendant in lesser crimes to perform community service, make restitution for damage due to the crime, obtain treatment for alcohol or drug problems and/or counselling for antisocial or mentally unstable conduct. If the defendant cooperates and the diversion results in progress, the charges eventually may be dismissed. Usually diversion may not be granted for a second offense. [definition from Californian based law.com dictionary, entered 8/10/2001 [http://dictionary.law.com/]]

>  Diversion is a system by which first-time offenders can be charged with a minor offence and escape without a conviction. <i>(Mar 15, 2004,Salient,No. 3/33</i>)

>  However Wellington Police Community Services Coordinator Detective Tony Moore disagrees, He sees youth initiatives like family group conferences and diversion as worthwhile. <i>(Nov 1, 2001,Contact (Wgtn),3</i>)

## dividing range
 
 <i>n.</i>

>  Resolved, That the Department be informed that the proposed road is inpracticable [sic], and recommending that a new road be surveyed on the diving range between the two roads. <i>(Dec 11, 1890,Wanganui Chronicle,2</i>)

>  Our guide shewed us another small valley three miles nearer the Lake than the one through which we had travelled, where he said there was a path leading to the valley of the Pakuratahi; with a little time devoted to asertain where a line may be carried, so as to avoid the highest points of the dividing range of hills, I have no doubt a road may be made so as readily to unite Wairarapa with the valley of the Hutt, at a cost perfectly insignificant, if we regard the extent of level and fertile land which it would be the means of rendering available, or the advantages it would confer on the first and principal settlement. <i>(Dec 22, 1841,New Zealand Gazette & Wellington Spectator,3</i>)

>  The eastern boundary proceeds from the Mokutapu, thence along the summit of the dividing range of the Maitai and Pelorus for a distance of eight miles, from thence the southern boundary commences, and proceeds in a straight line to the southern angle of section No. 8 Suburban South, thence along the northern boundary of sections Nos. 19, 99, 76, 75, and 77, Waimea East district, to high-water mark. <i>(Nov 8, 1851,Nelson Examiner and New Zealand Chronicle,148</i>)

>  ".. Eighteen years afterwards, far on the eastern side of the big dividing range, and near the Hutt River, some bushfellers found the bones of the hapless lad." <i>(Aug 5, 1921,Ashburton Guardian,4</i>)

>  <b>GLEN</b> Biddy did not half do her lolly. The effort cost me a shirt, a torn pair of good working trousers . <i>(1980,Bush in Our Yard,33</i>)

>  <b>McGill</b> lolly any sweets, short for lollipop. NZA. - chuck or lose your lollies to spew. - do one's lolly lose one's temper. NZA <i>(1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,70</i>)

 <i>phr.</i>

## do over
 
 <i>v.</i> to treat (usu. a person) harshly, roughly or dishonestly; to thrash; to scold severely. a. ?????

>  <b>BURGESS</b> ... and since we are going to do these people over (his very words) I think we had better prevent him from doing us any harm hereafter. <i>(1866,Confessions,118,1983 ed.</i>)

>  <b>MUIR</b> You're bloody lucky I don't do you over just for being such a nark. <i>(1960,Word for Word,255</i>)

>  <b>SYDER & HODGETTS</b> To beat up, perhaps savagely. .in 4;`His pals knew he gave information to the police, so theywaited for him and done him over. ## do the block
 
 <i>phr.</i> to promenade or parade the streets [1869. Marcus Clarke, `Peripatetic Philosopher,' (in an Essay on `Doing the Block') (reprint), p. 13:]

>  <b>MORRIS</b> <i>Block, doing the</i> v. lounging in the fashionable promenade. In Melbourne, it is Collins Street, between Elizabeth and Swanston Streets. In Sydney, `The Block' is that portion of the city bounded by King, George, Hunter, and Pitt Streets. It is now really two blocks, but was all in one till the Government purchased the land for the present Post Office, and then opened a new street from George to Pitt Street. Since then the Government, having purchased more land, has made the street much wider, and it is now called Martin's Place. <i>Ibid.</i> 37 <i>Block, on the (1) On the promenade above referred to. </i> <i>(1898,Austral English,36</i>)

>  <b>O'REGAN</b> The gilded loafer `does the block' and elevates his snout/ To see the rough-dressed fossicker, white haired and broken down/ Who strays from out the lonely wilds for his Christmas booze in town. <i>(1894,Voices of Wave and Tree,15</i>)

>  `We may slacken pace a little now and again, just as the busy man, who generally walks quickly, has to go slowly in the crowd on the Block.' <i>(Jul 17, 1896,Argus, The,4/7</i>)

>  <b>BAKER</b> ... to do the block ... : these are phrases which come almost as easily to the New Zealand tongue as to the Australian. <i>(1941,NZ Slang,62</i>)

>  <b>SUTTON-SMITH</b> Once or twice we [sc a boys' impromptu band] `did the block,' but I am afraid our collection was even more inadequate to our supposed needs than the Army's was to theirs. A Guy Fawkes appeal was much better supported. The Army was considered either irreverent or a pest. (1880-90; New Plymouth) <i>(1981,History of Children's Play,67</i>) [NOTES: [c1880-1890 New Plymouth]]

>  <b>WALKER</b> [The engaged couple] were `doing the block' - Hereford St. <i>(1902,Zealandia's Guerdon,176</i>)

>  The writer of this was almost gathered to his fathers the other night when he met a fat Chow `doing the block' in the dour city. <i>(Dec 18, 1909,NZ Truth,234/5/4</i>)

>  <b>WILLIAMS & REEVES</b> You do the block in swagger style, in <i>such</i> a clever gown. <i>(1891,In Double Harness,54</i>)

## do the Pacific Slope
 
 <i>phr.</i> (of a wanted criminal) to flee the country

>  <b>WALKER</b> Perhaps he [sc a missing man] accomplished the `Pacific Slope'. <i>Ibid.</i> 326 He [sc.the detective] has packed so many `confidence men' off to penitentiary ... that the others have done the `Pacific Slope' in various directions, chiefly towards Australia. <i>(1902,Zealandia's Guerdon,292</i>)

>  <b>GILKISON</b> In the 'seventies and 'eighties many fraudulent debtors, embezzlers and rich thieves escaped from New Zealand before arrest, by doing what came to be known as the `Pacific Slope'. Someone discovered that the Sandwich Islands, which were then ruled by a native queen, had no extradition treaty with New Zealand and consequently rogues who were much `wanted' by the police in this country on reaching Honolulu could laugh at writs and law proceedings. <i>(1938,Early Days of Canterbury,133</i>)

>  <b>MULGAN</b> `Poor old Tom! He's never been the same since his partner did the Pacific slope.' <i>(1934,Spur of Morning,42</i>)

>  <b>GORE</b> He never returned. Tetley had done what in those days was termed `The Pacific Slope', and was last heard of in South America, that haven for absconders and those anxious to shelve their responsibilities. <i>(1956,Levins,186</i>)

>  The employes [sic] at a certain flaxmill in the district (says the "Manawatu Times") awoke one morning to find that their overseer had "done the Pacific slope" with nearly GBP200 of their wages in his pocket. <i>(Jun 4, 1902,Tuapeka Times,3</i>) [NOTES: Reprinted from the Manawatu Times]

>  The Wanganui Chronicle says: The latest idea in "sweeps" is what is known as the "Pacific Slope" stakes. All the names of the prominent business men are entered, and the drawer of the next person who leaves his Wanganui creditors and crosses the Pacific, scoops the pool. We hear that the stakes are large, so it may be worth the while of the holder of them to do the "slope" himself. <i>(Nov 19, 1889,North Otago Times,4</i>)

## dob in
 
 <i>v.</i> to inform on, to betray to authorities.

>  <b>Dave Armstrong</b> 'Well, I did tell the Maoris that if they didn't agree to my little "tiriti" ,' chuckled Janet, 'I'd ring up Fisheries and dob them in for poaching.' <i>(2007,Six Pack 2, The,116</i>)

>  <b>SYDER & HODGETTS</b> To deliberately betray, or, in a less serious situation, to deliberately reveal detrimental information concerning another - naturally to his disadvantage. .in 4;`They reckoned nobody had the slightest clue, but it looks as if someone was watching them. The police walked up to their tent while they were still asleep. Somebody dobbed them in alright.' <i>(1974,Australian & NZ English [TS],273</i>) [NOTES: (1962-63)1974 Syder and Hodgetts Aust and NZ English [TS] 273]

>  `My father said are you going to dob me in to the farmer,' he said. <i>(Feb 22, 1984,Dominion,5</i>)

>  The pre-teen courier was dobbed in by a nine-year-old classmate and taken away for a chat with some friendly policemen who immediately recognised the `lucerne' for what it was. <i>(Oct 19, 1986,Sunday News,7</i>)

>  <b>MITCALFE</b> `Thank you, Sir!' said Winston, glad to be out and free, glad, too, to know who it was that `dobbed them in'. <i>(1985,Hey Hey Hey,103</i>)

>  <b>McGILL</b> dob in to betray; to contribute funds; to put someone in trouble, perhaps oneself; eg `Watch your step with him, he'll dob you in for the hell of it.' <i>(1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,37</i>)

>  Unless people are prepared to `dob in' welfare cheats, Social Welfare Minister Michael Cullen has warned, demand will grow for the state to gain coercive powers it should not have. <i>(Mar 26, 1990,Dominion,18</i>)

## docker
 
 <i>n.</i> a tantrum; fit of angry struggling.

The docker noted the sex, then earmarked accordingly. <i>(1989,Pioneer's Life, A,90</i>)



 
 <i>n.</i> [timber milling]

## docking
 
 <i>n.</i> removing a large part of a young animal's (usu. lamb's) tail to stop dung sticking to it, leaving behind the `dock', or part of the tail (with tailing the usu. term in NZ (OED2 dock v1. 1 b. 1491), and generates some special combinations)

>  It knocks the sheep about too much to doother than have one principal muster fordocking. <i>(Oct 16, 1912,Otago Witness,16</i>)

>  It was the docking... It reminded me of the execution of Mary Queen of Scots. <i>(Mar 25, 1943,NZ Farmers' Weekly,39</i>)

>  The docking, the crutching, the shearing, everyone's involved and we each had our own little jobs. <i>(Jan 2000,North & South,92</i>)

>  She said the farmers have been in here talking about docking one week, and the next, counting their stock losses. <i>(Dec 1992,Metro,15</i>)

>  Parliament just gave a first tick to Labour's Dianne Yates's bill to ban tail docking ... Depending on what the dog is likely to be doing, they argue, docking is actally a great kindness. <i>(Nov 13, 2004,Listener (New Zealand Listener),35</i>)

>  Nearly 17 per cent. loss of lambs through docking is an extraordinary occurrence. <i>(Oct 22, 1887,Auckland Weekly News,31</i>)

>  <b>A9</b> Docking and fencing are right up my street. <i>(Jun 16, 2003,Dominion Post</i>)

>  The knife could soon fall on the practice of docking dogs' tails.... A ban on tail docking was first put forward as part of the Animal Welfare Bill in 1999, but dropped after widespread opposition to the ban put the entire bill at risk. <i>(Jan 18, 2004,Dominion Post,A5</i>)

>  The castration and docking of lambs is animportant yearly procedure on farms wheresheep are bred. <i>(1920,NZ Journal of Agriculture,XXI/142</i>)

>  DOCKING. The operation of cutting thetail off the lamb is usually carried outimmediately before the animal isreleased. <i>(1934,NZ Journal of Agriculture,XLIX/224</i>)

>  <b>BELSHAW</b> Lambs have two well-defined periods ofrisk, namely, immediately following andresulting from docking and castration. <i>(1936,Agricultural Organization in NZ,425</i>)

>  There are three common methods of docking tails: by using the knife, the searing-iron, or the rubber ring... The searing or docking iron must be at 'black heat', not red hot... Docking by the searing iron is quite efficient if carefully carried out. <i>(1950,NZ Journal of Agriculture,199</i>)

>  Experience included dipping, dagging, crutching, footrotting and docking. <i>(Jun 2001,NZ Memories,No. 30/43</i>)



 
 <i>n.</i>

Docking is Northspeak for marking, but wherever it is you have to muster the sheep, yard them and do unspeakable things like dagging, drenching, earmarking, tailcutting and a considerable amount of castration. <i>(2000,High Times in the High Country,168</i>)

 <i>n.</i> ? a pickpocket [(prisoners') ca1941-1945 Riverside Community]

## Dog Town
 
 <i>n.</i> (derogatory) an early nickname for Port Chalmers (cf. the occasional PIGTOWN for Picton) [(coastal seamen's) ca1920 Pugh-Williams p.c.May 1951 Port Chalmers, perhaps because it comprises the proverbial `only one man and a dog' only.]

>  <b>BOWMAN</b> During the [1890] strike about 100 seamen unattached in Port Chalmers stayed in hotels and boarding houses, but a large number of them found residence in the "baches" in what was called "Sweat Rag Alley", consisting of a number of small baches or cribs in a double row where the Corporation Yard now is. Each bach housed three or four men and it was said that each man had a dog. From this fact, the area became known as "Dogtown". <i>(1948,Port Chalmers,53</i>)

>  To the uninitiated this may mean nothing, but, to those in the know, the quickest way to cause a riot and to raise an insurrection is to call an inhabitant of Port Chalmers a dweller in Dogtown. <i>(Jul 8, 1911,NZ Truth,315/7/1</i>)

>  <b>CRYER</b> There are two explanations for the term Dog Town. The first has its clue in the name of the town, Port Chalmers, which obviously had a lot of docks. As with the Isle of Dogs in London, there is a belief that in the old days the docks of Port Chalmers caused it to be referred to as Dock Town, and the word became corrupted. But there are also legends that.. there were always many seamen about, sometimes unemployed, and all of them were accompanied by their dogs. Most of these men lived in cottages in George Street which became known locally as Dog Town and the name spread to mean Port Chalmers in general. It's occasionally heard even today. <i>(2001,Curious Questions,63</i>)

>  <b>STEWART</b> And during the troubles [sc. an 1890 strike] , about 100 seamen from other ports stayed in baches in an area called 'Sweat Rag Alley' in Port Chalmers. I t was said that each resident there had a dog - and the name 'Dogtown' unfortunately stuck to the Borough for a long time. <i>(1973,Days of Fortune,42</i>)

>  <b>PATOKA REUNION COMMITTEE</b> Prior to the 1930s the dogtrial dances were a feature of the social calendar. [dogtrial dance] <i>(1985,Podocarp to Pasture,64</i>)



## dog trial stick
 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) a stick less than a metre in length that is used to prompt sheep or dog in a dog trial contest.

>  <b>GORDON</b> After the dog, the only other assistance or weapon a triallist can have is what a British shepherd would call a crook, but to us is simply a dog trial stick. It is much shorter than an overseas triallist's crook - it can't be longer than a metre - and it can be used only to wave at sheep .. sheep can run into a trial stick. <i>(1998,Three Sheep and a Dog,8</i>)

>  <b>GORDON</b> The crook, or as we usually call it, dog trial stick, is very much the focus of unwitting attention and nervous release. [trial stick] <i>(1998,Three Sheep and a Dog,201</i>)



## dog trialist
 
 <i>n.</i>

>  Until last year, Australian dog triallists competed in separate state-run competitions... Australian triallists don't have huntaways (those loud barking dogs) and, while in New Zealand the trials use a combination of human and dog, the Aussies have the dog do all the work. <i>(Sep 9, 1989,Listener (New Zealand Listener),11</i>)

>  <b>NEWTON</b> He had been recommended to me by Bert Benbow, an old mustering mate and now a leading New Zealand dog trialist. <i>(1966,Boss's Story, The,157</i>)



 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) a sheep-dog owner who enters dog trial contests.

>  <b>MCGREGOR</b> The four males were taken over by keen dog trialists of the district ... <i>(1980,Dog's Life, A,43</i>)

>  <b>KERR</b> Every dog triallist in New Zealand has trouble keeping three sheep together in the middle of a paddock out of the hook, the open enclosure that holds them for trialing. [dog triallist] <i>(2000,High Times in the High Country,147</i>)



## dog trialling
 
 <i>n.</i>

>  Vicki started dog trialling when she was about 12. <i>(Jul 8, 2000,Dominion,32</i>)

 <i>n.</i> (Rural) [mustering] running a dog when it is not necessary.

>  <b>LOUGHNAN</b> dog-trialling: wasting a mustering team's time by running a dog unnecessarily. [dog trialing; sheepdog trialing] <i>(1981,Loughnan Glossary,25</i>)



 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) a competition held on a specific hunting or heading course, where sheepdogs compete to work sheep faultlessly within a certain time.

## dog-leg
 
 <i>n.</i> a fence constructed of crooked sticks and branches held together by their own crookedness.

>  Now our stockyard is different from most - the only substantial part of it being the gate. The rest of it is what is usually known as 'dogleg' and is composed of small logs piled up, with an occasional post to keep them upright. [dog-leg fence] <i>(1926,NZ Dairyman,137</i>)

>  the log fence and the dog-leg are the cheapest, and most common on new clearings. <i>(1883,Brett's Colonists Guide,18</i>)

>  In fencing we have a number of different methods, from the primitive dog-leg to the more handsome and substantial post and wire. <i>(1887,NZ Farmer,July 196</i>)

>  <b>DONEY</b> Dog-leg is a good fence and stands two or three years if put up properly. <i>(1891,Essays on Bush-Farming,18</i>)



 
 <i>adj.</i> In full dogleg(ged) fence; applied to a primitive kind of fence made of rough timber or poles, crossed spars, which are the doglegs, placed at intervals, keep in place a low rail resting on short posts, and are themselves fixed by heavy saplings resting in the forks above (Morris); but see cits.

>  Dog'.leg fence'. (d&omacr.g'.l&ebreve.g f&ebreve.ns'.).} A kind of rough fence, Dog'.leg (d&omacr.g'.l&ebreve.g), n. } made of posts and rails. Light posts (about 3 ft. 6 in. in height) are arranged in pairs, crosswise, so as to form a fork about 18 in. from the top. Each fork supports a rail, which is laid slantwise and plaited in and out among the three or four neighbouring supports, its lower end being driven into the ground. Sometimes the whole is capped with a horizontal rail, laid from fork to fork. <i>(1898,Merriam-Webster Third International,2021</i>)

>  <b>McKENZIE</b> The `dog-legged' type of fence ... was apparently a purely Canadian type ... made of stakes of varying length and the trunks of small trees. <i>(1935,Gael Fares Forth, The</i>)

>  There was no fencing wire in those days [in Auckland ca1865] so we had to make what is called a `dog-leg fence'. This was composed of stakes driven crossways in the ground and the long sticks laid with one end on the ground and the other end on the crossed stakes. <i>(1943,Memoirs of Pioneers</i>)

>  <b>WILSON</b> The tiny flower patch surrounding the shack was protected by a dog-leg fence - that is a fence of crooked sticks and branches held together by their own crookedness. <i>(1955,Land of My Children,66</i>)

>  The dog-leg fence, found in North America only in the Maritime Provinces of Canada, reappeared in the Nova Scotian settlement at Waipu, and from there spread to some other bush settlements in the north. It was constructed by driving two crossing stakes into the ground, and in the notch of these placing a third rail which followed the direction of the fence ... It was claimed that it would keep out cattle, but the fence was never widely adopted probably because of its tendency to get out of repair easily. <i>(Oct 1965,NZ Geographer,147</i>) [NOTES: (Hargreaves `Farm Fences')]

>  <b>BOSWELL</b> So the farm gradually took shape. Small paddocks were fenced, first the crude `dog-leg' of roughly-split light posts, then post-and-rail and later barbed wire. <i>(1955,Dim Horizons,45,1956 ed.</i>)

>  dogleg adj. applied to primitive fence made of rough timber. <i>(1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),7</i>)

>  dog-leg fence NZ & Austral. zigzag fence made of logs supported on crossed poles. <i>(1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,221</i>) [NOTES: [nf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict.]]

>  <b>McGILL</b> doglegged shape of a crooked fence; from the proverbially crooked nature of a dog's hind leg, now more familiar in the dogleg approach to some golf holes. NZA. <i>(1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,38</i>)

## dog-skin
 
 <i>n.</i> the skin of the kuri or Maori dog, esp. as dogskin cloak, dogskin mat

>  ... in each of the Canoes were two or three Cheifs [sic] and the habits of these were superior to any we had yet seen, the Cloth they were made on was of the best sort and cover'd on the out side with Dog skins put on in such a manner as to look agreeable to the Eye. Few of these people were tattow'd or mark'd in the face like those we have seen farther to the south, but several had their Backsides tattou'd much in the same manner as the Inhabitants of the Islands within the Tropics. <i>(Nov 27, 1769,Cook's Journals,1/213,1955 ed.</i>)

>  <b>FORSTER</b> they had bits of dog-skin at the four corners of their cloaks.. The boghee-boghee, or shaggy-cloak, which hangs round their necks like a thatch of straw, was almost constantly worn by them ... <i>(1777,Voyage Round the World,1/214</i>)

>  <b>WILKES</b> In his hand [Pomare] usually carries a short cloak of dog-skin, called topuni, shupuni, or patutu. <i>(1852,U.S. Exploring Expedition,1/303</i>)

>  [The Maori men to the making] of their prized dog-skin, or Kiwi-feather, clothing mats ... <i>(1869,TrNZI,/III/8</i>) [NOTES: (Colenso Maori races)]



 
 <i>adj.</i> dogskin cloak, mat, robe

>  <b>WILLIAMS</b> He stood in silence leaning on the end of his musket, a bill-hook bright as silver in his belt in front, and a handsome dogskin mat thrown carelessly over his shoulders, ... <i>(Mar 6, 1832,Early Journals of Henry Williams, The,231,1961 ed.</i>)

>  <b>WILKES</b> He was very feeble, ... and clad in an old dog-skin robe. <i>(1853,U.S. Exploring Expedition,1/307</i>) [NOTES: 1840 Mar in 1852 Wilkes U.S. Exploring Expedition 1/307]

>  <b>MACLEAN</b> The elder men were dressed in their best dogskin and kaitaka mats, some of them had their heads decorated with huia and kotuku feathers, not neglecting their mere[es acute] pounamu (greenstone clubs), and every other ancient emblem of chieftainship ... <i>(May 26, 1848,Diary</i>) [NOTES: 1848 May 26 Maclean Diary in 1940 Cowan Sir Donald Maclean 36]

>  He gave me a dogskin mat made by the Ngaticahounas [Ngatikahungunu]. <i>(Mar 3, 1849,Torlesse Papers,72,1958 ed.</i>)

>  The early voyagers and the first residents of New Zealand all agree in stating that the Maori dog was unknown in the wild state. It was a purely domesticated species ... valued ... for supplying the material for their much prized dogskin mats ... <i>(1894,TrNZI,26/219</i>)

>  <b>COWAN</b> .. Te Rangihaeata rose, a tall gaunt savage in appearance, clothed in a dogskin mat. <i>(1940,Sir Donald Maclean,42</i>)

>  <b>SUTHERLAND</b> Apart from greenstone heirlooms, etc., the most valuable gifts that can be bestowed include the dogskin cloak, the korowai cloak with black edges, and the kiwi feather cloak. <i>(1941,Numismatic History of NZ,15</i>)

## dog-whistle/dog-whistle politics
 
 <i>n.</i> (politics) a concealed, coded, or unstated idea, usually divisive or politically dangerous, nevertheless understood by the intended hearers. [orig. Australian, now used worldwide]

>  Are you reading my mind Peter? That's exactly what this Jewish New Zealander was about to say. And there are more gay men in NZ than Jews, I'm sure. .. The whole idea of a "mainstream New Zealander" is bogus anyway .. except as dogwhistle code for "real New Zealander". Which is why Jordan's annoyed. And so am I. <i>(Jun 27, 2005,Internet - see Notes</i>) [NOTES: Just Left: Jordon Carter 27/6/2005 http://jtc.blogs.com/just_left/2005.06/gays_aren't_main.html]

>  This, say the critics, is pure dog-whistle, the subtle appeal to racism, sounded at a pitch that is heard only by the right ears. <i>(Jul 10, 2005,Sunday Star Times,C2</i>)

>  ... what are sometimes called dog whistle politics ... <i>(Jul 5, 2005,Radio NZ / National Radio,Nine to Noon</i>) [NOTES: Linda Clark interviewing Jane Clifton]

>  Critics say the pair - who run Crosby/Textor, a public relations and polling company with branches in Sydney, Melbourne, Canberra and London - specialise in "dog whistle politics" - fearmongering that preys on racial disquiet and prejudice ... Some say [they] did not help the Conservatives, whose share of the vote rose less than 1%, and that the dog-whistling backfired. ... <i>(Aug 14, 2005,Sunday Star Times,A8</i>)

>  That is a dog-whistle National does not want: one that sends the dog after rabbits instead of the ewes. <i>(Jun 28, 2005,NZ Herald,A11</i>)

>  The net also plays into the Tories' hands by facilitating the "dog-whistle" campaigning at which Michael Howard has become increasingly adept. Just as a dog-whistle is inaudible to humans but is heard by every canine within miles, Howard has been beaming messages at targeted groups-anti-abortion campaigners, and people hostile to immigrants, gypsies and asylum-seekers-which, if broadcast in the normal way, might repel the majority of voters. <i>(Apr 10, 2005,Internet - see Notes</i>) [NOTES: [the Observer, 10 Apr. 2005] quoted on www.worldwidewords.org/turnsofphrase/tp-dog2htm Not a Kiwi quote]

>  The crown was called a bull, a cartwheel, a caser, five bob, and most familiar of all a dollar, the latter dating from the time when the rate of exchange was four US dollars to the pound. The only instance recorded of Cockney rhyming slang term for a coin is Oxford scholar, the derivation from dollar being obvious. The half crown was called a half-dollar, a half-bull, half-caser, two-and-a-kick, and two-and-a-buck. In the latter instance buck stands for sixpence, though apparently this term was rarely used by itself for that coin denomination, but almost always in association with a number of shillings. The florin seems to have had fewer English nicknames, only two bob being recorded as being in use in New Zealand. <i>(Oct 1977,NZ Numismatic Journal,15</i>)

## doodlum-buck
 
 <i>n.</i> a children's game, toodle-em-buck q.v. [aka doodle-em buck, doodlum buck, toodle-em-buck]

>  There were fancy stalls, produce tents, butchers' shops, skittle alleys, a shooting gallery, the good old game of "Doodlum Buck," bowling alleys, prize quoit boards, etc. <i>(Apr 14, 1921,Ashburton Guardian,5</i>)

>  <b>SUTTON-SMITH</b> Pitching games were Pitch and Toss, Quoits, Ninepins, Egg Cap and Toodle-em-buck. In the game of Toodle-em-buck (Richmond ([19]19) a piece of broom a foot in length with a button on top of it stood upright in a circle of about two fet in diameter. Players pitched another piece of broom at this upright stick from a set distance in an endeavour to knock it over and send the button out of the circle. The game was played to the cry of `Roll up, Tumble up, come and play the game of Toodle-em-Buck'. There is still occasional mention of Egg Cap (Horoeka, Alexandra). <i>(1953,Unorganized Games,2/471</i>)

>  <b>SUTTON-SMITH</b> Another universal stone-throwing game was Ducks and Drakes (K-8), or Skipping Stones, which consisted simply in `skipping' flat stones across the water. feet in diameter and a button was placed on top of the stick. Players pitched another piece of broomstick of the same size at the upstanding piece in an attempt to knock it over and send the button outside the circle. The game was played to the cry of `Roll up, tumble up, come and play the game of Toodlle-em-buck.' <i>Ibid.</i> 172 An odd pitching game was Toodle-em-Buck (K-28) (Richmond, Nelson, 1919), in which a piece of broomstick a foot in length was placed upright in a circle about two <i>(1972,Folkgames of Children,167</i>)

>  <b>SUTTON-SMITH</b> There are games recorded in this period for which there is no record before 1900 though they may well have existed under other names. .. <i>Canterbury:</i> Poor Old Tom, Rats and Rabbits and Rips,Steps, Skin the Snake, Steal a Peg, Toodle-em-Buck, The Gag;... <i>(1981,History of Children's Play,231</i>)

>  [Gambling] which disgraces horse-racing, is benignly smiled upon by grandmotherly legislators who know as much of betting and turf gambling as they do of three card monte, or the ways of doodlum-buck. <i>(Nov 6, 1885,Wairarapa Daily,2</i>)

>  Soldiers' Day Attractions... Cocoanut shys... Doodle-em Buck. <i>(Apr 13, 1916,Stratford Evening Post,3</i>) [NOTES: My uncle used to often used the phrase "The great old game of doodle-em buck" apropos of almost anything which I suppose he must have picked up from a visiting side-show.]

>  <b>BRUCE</b> Peter Poski ... with his crown and anchor game and his confrere with his game of `Doodlum Buck', ... <i>(1932,Early Days of Canterbury,152</i>)

>  The various sports, under the superintendence of the committee, according to the programme, consisted of target shooting, target shooting with shot, quoit matches, wrestling, three-legged racing, vaulting with pole, putting the stone, egg racing, running flat leaps, standing high leaps, 300 yards handicap racing, pigeon shooting, hurdle racing, boys' racing, and hop, step, and jump; and last - though not least - "Doodle'em Buck" and the wheel-of-fortune. <i>(Dec 28, 1871,Grey River Argus,2</i>)

## Doolan
 
 <i>n.</i> a Roman Catholic; A Catholic, esp. an Irish Catholic (occas. Irishman); see also Micky Doolan. [ca1941 St Patrick's College, Silverstream]

>  <b>CAMPBELL</b> We'd gang up on kids who chucked off at us - like the boys from the Catholic home. They'd call us [from the Presbyterian Boys' Home in Dunedin] `Pressbuttons'; we'd call them `doolans', `doolies', `Mickey Doolans' - or worse. <i>(1984,Island to Island,87</i>) [NOTES: [c1935]]

>  <b>FINLAYSON</b> A holy medal, eh? Those jokers all doolans you know. <i>(1952,Brown Man's Burden,116,1973 ed.</i>) [NOTES: `Little Gift for Harry']

>  <b>SLATTER</b> And in peace the civilians must have something to hate too. The Dutchies or the Pommies or the Doolins or somebody. <i>(1959,Gun in My Hand, A,60</i>)

>  <b>BAXTER</b> I don't let any black bugger push me around. Or any Doolan either..<i>Ibid.</i> 36 `I'm not a Doolan, Ivan.' I know you're not. But if you're ever looking for a Church, don't by-pass the onewith the big stone steps ... <i>(1985,Horse,29,C.1962 ed.</i>) [NOTES: (Name and the Game)]

>  <b>PEARSON</b> They had called him `the Doolan bugger' - Doolan on their tongues meant Irish Catholic. <i>(1963,Coal Flat,63</i>)

>  <b>SLATTER</b> Webster had brutally reminded him that the original Crusaders had all been Doolins. <i>Ibid.</i> 195 There is a catholic college in the town now and we [in our rugby team] coulduse some of those ... kick everything in sight Doolins. <i>(1968,Pagan Game, The,92</i>)

>  <b>DAVIN</b> Not that she isn't worried enough about Eric, that's my steady in Wellington, him not being a doolan and all that. <i>(1970,Not Here, Not Now,57</i>)

>  <b>FINLAYSON</b> doolans: Catholics. <i>(1973,Brown Man's Burden,140</i>)

>  <b>AGNEW</b> `Yes, I'm a Doolan,' I pacified him. `At least I was baptised one.' ... It was only a short walk to the Catholic church ... . <i>(1974,Loner, The,100</i>)

>  <b>MASON</b> SMITHSON: `The New Roman Missal'! Good God. Are you becoming a Doolan now? <i>(1974,Swan Song,14</i>)

>  <b>LAWRY</b> This fellow measured far short of what they wanted for their daughter, and anyway, he was a `doolan'. <i>(1980,Good Luck & Lavender,77</i>)

>  <b>BAXTER</b> SKULLY. Once a Doolan always a Doolan. You've got holy water on the brain. <i>(1982,Collected Plays,39</i>) [NOTES: (1968) 1982 Baxter Collected Plays (Wide Open Cage) 39]

>  <b>BEARDSLEY</b> doolan Roman Catholic <i>(1984,Blackball 08,243</i>)

>  <b>McGILL</b> Spotted him for a Doolan right enough. Only several removed [sic: =?removes] from the priesthood. <i>(1985,G'day Country,102</i>)

>  Doolan NZ & Austral. sl. derog. Roman Catholic. [Irish name] <i>(1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,223</i>) [NOTES: [nf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict.]]

>  <b>McGILL</b> doolan Roman Catholic, usually expected to be Irish; presumably from Doolan being a common name here last century. <i>(1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,38</i>)

>  The Roman Catholic church (attended by `Micks' or `Doolans') was outside this ranking ... <i>(1988,Through the Looking Glass,127</i>) [NOTES: (Meikle)]

>  The dial tone suggested my luck with the Doolans had run out. <i>(Nov 18, 2004,TV3,17</i>)

## dopiness
 
 <i>n.</i> a deficiency disease; a form of bush sickness.

>  The worst soils for `dopiness' as the local farmers call the disease [sc. bush-sickness]. <i>(1929,TrNZI,59/412</i>) [NOTES: (Aston) [Te Kuiti district]]

>  Recent investigations ion New Zealand testify to ... the value of top dressing of pastyures with lime and superphosphate where sheep are affected with dopiness diseases. <i>(Nov 1932,Discovery,357/2</i>) [NOTES: [OED2]]

>  The known deficiency diseases in New Zealand apparently mainly due to the lack of some element in the food of farm animals are:- `Bush Sickness' or [mistakenly] Iron deficiency. `Dopiness' or Calcium deficiency. `Waihi Disease' or Phosphate deficiency. `Goitre' or Iodine deficiency... Bush sickness is always found in the volcanic district on coarse rhyolitic pumice soils and `dopiness' on soils derived from fine volcanic dust or mud showers. A soil on which `dopiness' develops is a leached loam and is found on deteriorated lands, i.e., lands which originally were highly fertile due to the ashes from the `bush burn,' the land subsequently becoming gradually less productive ... <i>(1936,Agricultural Organization in NZ,81</i>)

>  It is at lambing-time that the effect of grass-grub ravages is most severe. Ewes are low in condition and have missed the `green bite from the pastures ... The normal green-feed area ... is inadequate. The result is a high mortality in young lambs, an increased susceptibility of the ewe to `dopiness,' ... <i>(1943,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,23/323A</i>)

>  Some green, succulent feed just before and at lambing assists in the prevention of diseases associated with lambing - dopiness (twin lamb disease or ante-partum paralysis) and milk fever. <i>(Jul 1950,NZ Journal of Agriculture,33/3</i>)



 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) a state of lethargy in sheep suffering from milk fever, sleepy sickness or an associated disease.

>  .. antepartum paralysis or "dopiness" of ewes is a nutritional disease definitely associated, as a rule, with ewes falling off in condition at the approach of lambing. <i>(Feb 20, 1937,NZ Journal of Agriculture,111</i>)

>  The troubles which are most likely to affect the ewes are (i) ante-partum paralysis, or as the farmer more frequently calls it 'dopiness' 'twin-lamb disease' or 'sleeping sickness' ... <i>(Sep 1, 1937,NZ Farmer,36</i>)

>  All good sheepfarmers know that 'sleepy sickness' ('dopiness') in ewes can be prevented by proper feeding at the right time. <i>(Jul 22, 1971,NZ Farmer,64</i>)

## double
 
 <i>n.</i> a bet placed at the same time on two horses to win (often spec. races). cf doubles chart; cits needed.

>  A local boniface had a ticket on the winning double at Trentham on Wednesday and received nearly 250 [pounds] for his investment. <i>(Jul 14, 1906,NZ Truth,56/2/2</i>)

>  <b>KEINZLY</b> `It isn't a call-out, Mr Pilgrim, it's an invitation. He said to tell you he struck the double and they're having a hooley.' <i>(1960,Tangahano,71</i>)

>  He.. had admitted that he had been taking "doubles."... He had never admitted "running any doubles." <i>(Feb 5, 1924,Otago Witness,34</i>)

>  <b>BIRD</b> A man known as 'Jacko' ran a double on the two contests, 1/- for GBP5. <i>(1998,Viaducts against the Sky,130</i>)

>  Just as L'Allegro surprised an army of punters.. at Ellerslie in 1932, so did he amaze the optimistic double punters who took on every available shilling on offer about the Jonathan-Star Artist combination. <i>(Mar 14, 1934,NZ Truth,2</i>)



 
 <i>n.</i> to deceive; to use trickery (on) [ca1950 still used]

>  <b>ROCK</b> . come the double on me ... <i>(1880,Colonists,60</i>)



 
 <i>n.</i> a sheep which has missed a shearing. [(farming)]

>  <b>McLEOD</b> Double or double-fleecer Double: Sheep which has missed shearing once or more. <i>(1972,Mountain World,310</i>)

>  <b>NEWTON</b> When he took over [the station], the only domestic sheep were `roughies' - long tailers and doubles that had multiplied from those which had escaped the wind-up muster four years before. <i>(1973,Big Country,86,1977 ed.</i>)

>  It was away back where roads were unknown, ... and where a few hundred sheep annually evaded the shearing muster, and remained among the scrub and flax bushes to develop into`double-fleecers'. <i>(Apr 1904,NZ Illustrated Magazine,48</i>)

>  <b>GUTHRIE-SMITH</b> We lived on wild pig ... and the fat wild sheep and double-fleecers that could be raked in from river cliffs; ... <i>(1926,Tutira,224</i>)



 
 <i>n.</i> a two-ounce packet of prison tobacco. [(prison)]

>  <b>NEWTON</b> DOUBLE (n) Two-ounce packet of prison tobacco. <i>(1982,Big Huey, The,248</i>)



 
 <i>n.</i> twice the standard nip; also called double-header, doubler. Contrast Brit. large.

>  <b>HULME</b> `Too right you can. Double whisky.' And I get that from him and a jug and another couple of doubles and another jug. <i>(1986,Te Kaihau,79</i>)

>  <b>JOHNSTON</b> `We've got two doubles down him. Neat. ...' <i>(1981,Fish Factory,78</i>)

>  <b>HALEY</b> All I had to do was to pour one glass into the another and I'd have my double. ... `Double whisky,' I said. <i>(1989,Transfer Station,41</i>)



 
 <i>n.</i> of locks or doors, to be double-locked

>  <b>MacKENZIE</b> double locks put on the double so that they cannot be opened with ordinary keys <i>(1980,While We Have Prisons,96</i>)



 
 <i>n.</i> (Rural) [ell. double-fleecer or double-decker] a sheep that has missed at least one shearing.

>  <b>NEWTON</b> When he took over, the only domestic sheep were 'roughies' - longtailers and doubles that had multiplied from those which had escaped the wind-up muster four years before. <i>(1973,Big Country of the South Island,86</i>)



 
 <i>v.</i> short form of double-bank, also occas. as n.; see also dub. (See [double-bank](../D#double-bank))

>  Buggies in those days were almost unknown, and fully half the visitors arrived on horseback, many of the younger class 'double-banking.' <i>(1910,Tapanui Station,26</i>)

>  <b>NEWTON</b> And as the horse was too touchy to 'double-bank,' the shepherd had to leave the cook .. and head .. for another horse. <i>(1952,High Country Journey,105</i>)

>  <b>HUTCHINSON</b> An old grey mare was the first pre-school teacher and, as each boy graduated to more spirited pony, the next youngest had to double-bank behind the saddle. <i>(1981,Hutchinsons of New Zealand, The,44</i>)

>  <b>RICHARDS</b> He bought them a horse and told them to double-bank to school with the other riders. <i>(1989,Pioneer's Life, A,75</i>)



 
<b>2</b> <i>v.</i> carry a second person on (usu. the bar of) a bicycle; see also double, dub; double-dink [ca1920 W.H.B. Orsman (Havelock)]

>  <b>SCANLAN</b> As children they had walked along it to school, before they had a pony, on which they `double-banked'. <i>(1934,Winds of Heaven,42</i>)

>  Of course you soon learned to double-bank and take your girl-friend for a spin on a Saturdayafternoon. <i>(Sep 1, 1945,NZ Dairy Exporter,90</i>)

>  Of course you soon learned to double-bank and take your girl-friend for a spin on a Saturdayafternoon. <i>(Sep 1, 1945,NZ Dairy Exporter,90</i>)



 
<b>3</b> <i>v.</i> In various transf. uses.a. To fight, two men against one.

>  And the growlers double-bank him/ In the way they alway [sic] fight. <i>(1926,Transport Workers' Song Book,86</i>)

>  <b>PETERSON</b> One of my earliest recollections is of watching [?c1890s-1900s] ... one 5th November, while the boys let off their crackers.. One double banger seemed a dud. <i>(1981,Glasshouses,7</i>)



 
<b>3</b> <i>v.</i>

>  <b>LANCASTER</b> `I have to inform you ... that I engaged myself to two gentlemen last night and I don't want either of them. ...' ... `Two gentlemen. Double-banked. ...' <i>(1938,Promenade,134</i>)

 <i>n.</i>

<b>2</b> <i>n.</i> double fleecer [(farmers')]

 <i>n.</i> [(?whalers')]

>  Indeed, <i>down under</i> is first recorded as a noun here rather than in Australia (in 1905, ten years before the first Australian use, according to the <i>Australian National Dictionary (AND)</i>. <i>(Aug 2000,NZWords,4 : 1</i>)

>  <b>ANZAC</b> Anyway, the men from Down Under were real glad to see them. <i>(1916,On the Anzac Trail,72</i>)

>  <b>LEE</b> In those days Antipodes meant more than `down under.' The term imaginatively suggested the edge of the world. <i>(1934,Children of the Poor,10,1949 ed.</i>)

>  <b>SIMPSON</b> [A US writer] The little Dominion of New Zealand is the more or less happy land popularly known as `Down Under.' ... It is doubtful whether the origin of the term `Down Under' will ever be known. It first came into general use during the World War of 1914-18, when the New Zealanders who fought in the ill-starred Gallipoli campaign were referred to as `the men from Down Under', but that was not the start of it. This faraway land, it seems, was known as `Down Under' in some parts of England and Scotland before the birth of the present century. The first World War merely [put] the expression into wider usage. An Auckland artist, Mr Trevor Lloyd,made it the subject of one of his cartoons at the very beginning of that great upheaval, and at least one English war correspondent used the term when writing on Gallipoli. After the year 1918 the expression fell into disuse, but during the second World War it again became popular, and I think we must thank the Americans for its revival. ... In England it is also known as the Antipodes. <i>(1945,If You'd Care to Know,7</i>)

>  <b>SHERWOOD</b> He also uses expressions like `down under', which implies implies that there's something wrong with the Southern Hemisphere, and `Australasia', which implies a close connection between New Zealand and her bullying barbaric neighbour, ... <i>(1985,Botanist at Bay,18</i>)

## down-country
 
 <i>n.</i> The flat part of a country (as opposed to hilly regions). The noun (and aj and av phrases) is used mainly to distinguish the lower or flat country (often the plains) from the high-country (South Island) or hill country (NI); it also often connotes `thecoast', `the town', as distinguished from the back country (see also front country), as often New Zealand's flat land is coastal or towards the coast. The usage is US and`colonial'.

>  <b>LANCASTER</b> In the down-country. [title: sc Christchurch] - <i>(1904,Sons o' Men</i>)

>  Acland quoting 1872 Apr 4 Wakatip Mail Down Country. See COUNTRY <i>(Oct 14, 1933,Press, The,15</i>)



 
 <i>n.</i> the flat country on a farm as opposed to the high or hill country.

>  <b>STUDHOLME</b> At Waimate we ran Cross-bred sheep on the down-country and Merinos or Half-breds on the hills. <i>(1940,Te Waimate,97</i>)

>  <b>THOMSON</b> There's a subtle difference between back-country men and those enslaved to industry and commerce. ... `The blokes up here think with their hearts,' said one of my mates one night after a session in a country pub with a crowd of cullers, musterers and shearers. `Down country they only think with their heads.' <i>(1952,Deer Hunter: The Experiences of a NZ Stalker,20</i>) [NOTES: [?n in the dc; ?av equiv. up here] ']



 
<b>1</b> <i>adj.</i> (Rural) [of foot-hills, rolling and flat land] closer to settlement than the high country or back country.

>  It will be the duty of down-country farmers to get the shearing over as soon as it can be managed, in order that the men go up country. <i>(Nov 1917,NZ Farmer,1226</i>)

>  <b>STEVENS</b> The new comb will also find full use in down-country flocks for the out-of-season shearing of breeding ewes, young sheep and rams. <i>(1958,Sheep.  Part 1, Sheep husbandry,81</i>)

>  <b>VANCE</b> The stock and station agency tried to put down-country sheep on Rollesby. <i>(1965,High Endeavour,208</i>)

>  The down-country cockies like nothing better than a nice line of blacks and will pay accordingly. <i>(Sep 10, 1970,NZ Farmer,35</i>)

>  <b>LOUGHNAN</b> One may detect in those who live up-country a slight hint of envy which is cloaked under a pose of smugness and scorn for down-country dwellers and which needs to be kept hidden because the down-country men do arrive at the annual ewe fairs to spend lots of money! <i>(1981,Loughnan Glossary,28</i>)

>  <b>HALL</b> Down-country sheep often look a bit pink after shearing because they're closely shorn, but in the high country a bit more wool has to be left on them. <i>(1987,Shepherd's Year,  A,21</i>)



 
<b>2</b> <i>adv.</i> towards or on the flat land near the coast; towards or near the town (esp. send (animals etc.) down country).

>  <b>BATHGATE</b> A dozen or more with their pack-saddles empty ... were returning down country. <i>(1874,Colonial Experiences,135</i>)

>  <b>BARRY</b> We were mustering the sheep and getting ready to start down-country.<i>Ibid.</i> 263 I sent herdown-country [sc. to Dunedin] in a coach. <i>(1879,Some Ups and Downs in NZ&A,20</i>)

>  <b>BEATTIE</b> Once or twice he had gone down-country with an empty dray ... <i>(1939,First White Boy Born in Otago,133</i>)

>  <b>BEATTIE</b> Another fire, started up about Greenvale in 1858, came `lolliping' down-country over the Merino Downs country, finally dying out about Waipahi. <i>(1947,Early Runholding in Otago,25</i>)

>  <b>BEATTIE</b> After being at Hogburn the best part of a year he decided to leave before the worst of the winter came on and so he returned down-country. <i>(1947,Pioneer Recollections,3,1956 ed.</i>) [NOTES: [Hogburn =Naseby]]

>  When an inhabitant of the Mackenzie goes beyond Burke's Pass, he talks of going `down country.' The phrase implies a moral as well as a physical descent. <i>(1948,Our Own Country,122</i>) [NOTES: (from Korero, AEWS magazine) 122 (`Mackenzie Country')]

Six months later he was back again ... He'd got footrot down on the `mud flats' and had to come back to the hard country. <i>(1952,High Country Journey,20</i>)

>  <b>THOMSON</b> The deer hides from the same parties were brought here by packhorses for a final check, then stored until transported down country to skin buyers or agents. <i>(1952,Deer Hunter: The Experiences of a NZ Stalker,66</i>)

## dracophyllum
 
 <i>n.</i> genus of trees and shrubs

>  So lonely below the tupare and dracophyllum. It is inhabited by ghosts. <i>(Jan 4, 2003,Listener (New Zealand Listener),18</i>)

>  <b>BIDWILL</b> As we went on, the land became more and more barren and level, till it became a mere moor, without a shrub, and almost without vegetation; a few bushes of the miserable-looking Dracophyllum being all that occurred to break the monotony of the plain. <i>Ibid.</i> 100 I here first saw the great Dracophyllum; it formed a small tree about six inches in diameter, and twenty feet high; it is one of the most curious plants in the world; the leaves grow in tufts at the ends of the branches, just as in the dragon tree (Dracaena), and are the same shape, but in this species they are elegantly reflexed, like the feathers of a soldier's plume; they are a foot long and an inch broad at the base. <i>(1841,Rambles in NZ,53,1952 ed.</i>)

## draft
 
 <i>n.</i>

>  <i>Ibid.</i> 162 The climax came to a head, when on a draft of stud ewes paddocked handy and pushed in on the late afternoon, to make a handy mob before Saturday half-day gave all a welcome respite from duty. `... My extra choice store lambs are [pound]1 per head'. That evening a Mr. Wright ... asked casually if an offer could be procured of 800 to 1000 lambs for immediate fattening. `Yes,' said Jim, `I know of a draft,' roughly describing same. ...' `I leave to-morrow for Fielding [sic] to attend a sheep sale there, and may pick up some suitable fattening lambs.' <i>(1960,Memories of Maoriland,49</i>)

>  He obtained the good average of 49 guineas for his draft. <i>(Nov 22, 1937,King Country Chronicle,5</i>)

>  <b>NEWTON</b> We had a small draft of sale ewes that year. <i>(1966,Boss's Story, The,88</i>)



 
 <i>n.</i> a group of animals separated from a main mob for a special purpose.

>  draft n. a body of cattle, etc., separated from a herd; ... <i>(1929,Whitcombe's Etym. Dict. Aust-NZ Suppl.,4</i>)

>  draft v.tr. to separate or sort cattle. n. the separated body of cattle. <i>(1966,NZ Contemp. Dict. (Aust.-NZ Suppl.),165</i>)

>  draft ... 7. Austral. & N.Z. a group of livestock separated from the rest of the herd or flock. ... 12. Austral. & N.Z. a. to select (cattle or sheep) from a herd or flock. b. to select (farm stock) for sale. <i>(1982,Collins Concise English Dictionary,336</i>) [NOTES: [See NZPOD 226, DRAFTING; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 146]]



 
 <i>v.</i>

>  <b>PHILLIPS</b> All hands drafting at woolshed - <i>(Jan 3, 1867,Journal Kept at Rockwood and the Point,91 ed.</i>)

>  <b>T.C. KIERNAN</b> C.H.S. and T.S. drafting and putting shorn sheep out to the paddocks. <i>(Feb 27, 1879,Diary,91</i>) [NOTES: 1879 Feb 27 T.C. Kiernan Diary in 1921 Guthrie Smith Tutira 127]



 
 <i>v.</i> to remove certain animals from a group by separating them or by driving them up a race and removing them through a drafting gate.

>  <b>DUNCAN</b> First we had to draft [the sheep] off and boat them across the arm of the lake. <i>(1888,Wakatipians,64</i>)

>  <b>STRONACH</b> Arriving at Tarndale, we drafted off the woollies and sent them to Molesworth to be shorn. <i>(1953,Musterer on Molesworth,37</i>)

>  Draft off: Removing certain animals from a group. This can be done by driving the animals out of a group (cut off or drift off) or driving them up a race and removing them through a special gate (drafting gate). <i>(1982,MAF Agricultural Glossary,5</i>)



 
 <i>v.</i> to sort (farm animals) into particular groups; to separate a large mob into smaller groups.

>  <b>BOWEN</b> With the race and gates shown sheep can be drafted six ways. <i>(1955,Wool Away!,123</i>)

>  The sheep drafted in through a race from the yards into pens running down the centre of the shed, were taken from these pens by the shearers. <i>(Sep 23, 1924,Otago Witness,54</i>)

>  finished drafting wethers which were put accross [sic] Wedderburn ... Number including hogs about 1540 <i>(Nov 11, 1859,Puketoi Station Diary</i>)

>  ... got a small mob into the yards 19 of which we selected and it took us the rest of the day to draft them ... <i>(Apr 11, 1862,Chudleigh Diary,32,1950 ed.</i>)

>  The armies of sheep were only being drafted (that is sorted) for sale. <i>(Mar 28, 1867,Richmond-Atkinson Papers,2/237,1960 ed.</i>) [NOTES: (C.W. Richmond)]

>  <b>WILLIAMS & REEVES</b> Dagging the hoggets, or drafting the rams. <i>(1889,Colonial Couplets,9</i>)

>  <b>WILSON</b> The sheep ... are ... placed in smaller ... enclosures adjoining the wool-sheds, from which are drafted, from time [243] to time, a number sufficient to keep the pens ... full. <i>(1894,In the Land of the Tui,242</i>)

>  Draft: (i) To divide stock into classes, either in a yard or (cattle) by cutting out (q.v.). In the old days sheep were hand drafted, i.e. lifted over a rail or manhandled through agate. (Butler A First Year in Canterbury Settlement],p.135) About 1864 it was found possible to run sheep one at a time through a drafting race and move a single gate as they came, so drafting into two lots. See double gate. Cattle are usually now drafted in a stock-yard (q.v.). See also shed. (G.P. W.) (ii) A number of stock sent for sale, e.g. `The annual Stonyhurst draft of four-year-old ewes will be offered.' When the draft is actually offered it is usually spoken of as a line. ([1898 Morris Austral-English]) <i>(Oct 14, 1933,Press, The,15</i>) [NOTES: (Acland Gloss.)]

>  <b>CHERRILL</b> Sometimes she would draft a mob to the stock yards, but ... prices ran low. <i>(1950,Story of a NZ Sheepfarm,113</i>)

>  <b>SCOTT</b> Presently Larry was summoned to help draft the sheep. <i>(1953,Breakfast at Six,34</i>)

>  draft ... v.i. to sort cattle, etc., into different groups. <i>(1929,Whitcombe's Etym. Dict. Aust-NZ Suppl.,4</i>)

>  draft v.t. to separate or sort cattle; n. separated body of cattle. <i>(1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),7</i>)

>  <b>McLEOD</b> Drafting sheep: The process of dividing a mixed mob into sexes or ages or any other required types. <i>(1970,Glorious Morning,253</i>)

>  When witness had finished "dagging," hedrafted the sheep. <i>(Oct 24, 1914,Stratford Evening Post,2</i>)



 
 <i>v.</i> (Rural) to sort or separate stock, especially sheep, for the purposes of sale, breeding, pasture management or treatment.

>  Finished drafting wethers ... <i>(Nov 11, 1859,Puketoi Station Diary</i>)

>  <b>WILLIAMS & REEVES</b> Dagging the hoggets or drafting the rams. <i>(1889,Colonial Couplets,9</i>)

>  <b>MOWAT</b> Mustered the sheep out of the house paddock, put them in the yards and drafted them. <i>(Oct 8, 1914,Alexander Mowat Diaries</i>)

>  <b>MAF</b> Draft off or drafting: Removing certain animals from a group. <i>(1982,MAF Agricultural Glossary,5</i>)



 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) an animal or group of animals that is separated from others in the process of drafting for sale, treatment or culling.

>  <b>NEWTON</b> The coastal flats of Homewood and the adjoining properties are great fattening country, producing big drafts of fat stock. <i>(1969,Big Country of the North Island,48</i>)

 <i>n.</i>

## drafting gate
 
 <i>n.</i>

>  <b>BOWEN</b> The sheep are also more easily seen by the man on the drafting gate when walking up hill. <i>(1955,Wool Away!,119</i>)

>  In drafting one sheep witness thought wasaccused's ran into his lot and witnesscould not catch it at the drafting gate. <i>(Oct 24, 1914,Stratford Evening Post,2</i>)



 
 <i>n.</i> a two-way gate in a drafting-race for separating farm animals into special groups.

>  <b>RIVES</b> After dinner we draughted out strangers and woolly ones and a devilish hard job I had standing at one of the draughting gates counting out the woolly ones. <i>(Feb 26, 1875,Jottings on the Spot,7</i>)

>  Drafting gates 3ft. wide. <i>(Sep 20, 1916,NZ Journal of Agriculture,220</i>)

>  <b>STUDHOLME</b> In later years we had stockyards at different parts of the Station where the drafting was done. The cattle were driven up a narrow race, with double gates at the further end, which were worked by a man standing on a platform. These yards were specially built for handling wild cattle, and had narrow gaps between the hinge of the drafting gate and post, through which a man could escape from a charging beast. <i>(1940,Te Waimate,136,1954 ed.</i>)

>  <b>ACLAND</b> He could hardly tell his own buggy horses ... and would never take the drafting gate ... <i>(1946,Early Canterbury Runs,153</i>)

>  <b>NEWTON</b> DRAFTING: The main feature of sheepyards is the drafting race. This race, perhaps eight yards in length, is only wide enough for sheep to pass through in single file; at the end of the race are two swinging gates which can be manipulated to turn the sheep into different yards, and so separate them into different `lines' or mobs. <i>(1949,High Country Days,194</i>)

>  drafting-gate A gate used in separating cattle and sheep into classes or herds. <i>(1958,Whitcombe's Modern Junior Dictionary (8th edn),131,8th ed.</i>)

>  drafting gate n. gate used to separate sheep or cattle <i>(1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),7</i>)

>  <b>FERNANDEZ</b> The boss was there working the drafting gate - two-tooths to the left-hand gate, six-tooths to the right. <i>(1973,Tussock Fever,1</i>)

>  Draft: Removing certain animals from a group. This can be done by driving the animals out of a group (cut off or drift off) or driving them up a race and removing them through a special gate (drafting gate). -->to remove certain animals from a group driving the animals out of a group (cut off or drift off) or driving them up a race and removing them through a special gate (drafting gate). <i>(1982,MAF Agricultural Glossary,5</i>)



 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) one of a pair of gates in a drafting race that is used to separate stock into two or three mobs.

## drafting yard

## draw
 
 <i>v.</i> in absol use, of a harpoon, to draw out. [(whalers')]

>  1 P.M. saw a whale ... Mate got fast but his Iron drew - <i>(Jul 16, 1836,Piraki Log,39</i>)



 
 <i>n.</i> [(Northland bushmen's)] (See [also sliver](../A#also-sliver),[stringer](../S#stringer))

>  <b>ROY GILBERD</b> [The fibres of wood in a tree just about to fall] do not part all in one plane and `stringers' or `drawers' are drawn out of the barrel, sometimes several feet long. Sometimes men on contract, trying to save timber, place their saw-cut too low and some of the wood-fibres break off up in the barrel. These are `stringers' while they are breaking, and `slivers' or `drawers' when they are left upright in the sloven. <i>(1950,Letter</i>) [NOTES: (Northland)]

>  <b>REED</b> A `draw' was a serious defect, but was not due to any fault in the living tree. When a tree fell before it was quite severed, it sometimes, in the act of falling, wrenched or `drew' out a portion of the butt, leaving great jagged, fang-like splinters adhering to the stump. The damage was, of course, always to the heart wood ... [<i>Ibid.</i> 156 [Edward Thompson] ... very often, before the saw got within a foot or so of the front scarf, the tree would start to fall gradually, and the uncut timber between the saw and the front scarf would have to break, and seldom cleanly; the heart, being more brittle than the sap, would break here and there, several feet above where thesawcut would have been standing straight. As the tree fell, these pieces, still attached to the stump, would draw out of the tree, and being almost heart-wood constituted the chief defect we call `draws'. <i>(1953,Story of the Kauri, The,151</i>) [NOTES: [?c1900]]

 <i>n.</i> In NZ of two main types,(1) a high-platformed two-wheeled shafted single-horse-drawn cart with sides, often a `spring dray'; and (2) in early settlement, a bullock-dray-->, a usu. four-wheeled pole-wagon without sides (occas. draycart--> (OED2 1719) as in:

The term drifting was used more specifically for driving on a reef, while the term crosscutting referredto tunnelling across the reef up to an angle of say forty-five degrees; however it was common to talk of `driving a crosscut'. <i>(1978,Gold Mining at Waihi,184</i>)

## drive
 
 <i>v.</i> to fall a group of trees whose trunks have been partially cut through, and so placed that the impetus of falling a chosen one will set off a `chain reaction'. See drive n2.. [(bushmen's)]

>  <b>BELL</b> Harry had just given the last cut of the axe to a big rimu, which, after a far premonitory cracks as it began to move, fell, driving before it in its line of fall a dozen or so of the smaller trees, which had been `scarfed' or cut partly through in readiness, and skilfully, so that each, when struck, might again in its turn strike and bring down another. The noise of a fall or drive of this kind is like thunder - loud, prolonged, reverberating. <i>Ibid..</i> 94 Harry had planned a big drive with a combined rimu and rata ... had `scarfed' all the smaller trees in front of it down to the already felled bush, and expected, when it was brought down, that it would send to earth the whole of these, driving one upon another far beyond the reach of its own length ... <i>(1899,In the Shadow of the Bush,83</i>)

>  <b>RICHARDS</b> The three [15] brothers spent the first few weeks clearing, learning the art of chopping, scarfing, driving and working a face. <i>(1986,Off the Sheep's Back,14</i>)



 
 <i>v.</i> (Rural) [machine shearing] to push through the wool with a deliberate stroke.

>  <b>BOWEN</b> This results in the wool often pulling the skin out, which makes it sometimes difficult to 'drive' with a full comb without marking the sheep. <i>(1955,Wool Away!,133</i>)



 
 <i>v.</i>

>  <b>BOWEN</b> ... the Corriedale produces a big weight of wool, and yet has the tender, loose skin of the Merino. This results in the wool often pulling the skin out, which makes it sometimes difficult to `drive' with a full comb without marking the sheep. <i>(1955,Wool Away!,133</i>)



 
 <i>n.</i> the falling of a group of trees by partially cutting through their trunks and falling a specially chosen tree so that the impetus of its fall sets off a `chain reaction'. [(bushmen's)]

>  <b>BELL</b> Harry had just given the last cut of the axe to a big rimu, which, after a far premonitory cracks as it began to move, fell, driving before it in its line of fall a dozen or so of the smaller trees, which had been `scarfed' or cut partly through in readiness, and skilfully, so that each, when struck, might again in its turn strike and bring down another. The noise of a fall or drive of this kind is like thunder - loud, prolonged, reverberating. <i>(1899,In the Shadow of the Bush,83</i>)

>  <b>KOEBEL</b> [drive n and v.t. described as scarfing trees in a line (on a rise), then falling the back one to push the rest down in a line.] <i>(1911,In Maoriland Bush,61</i>)

>  <b>CARR</b> Even the most experienced men sometimes get caught by a falling tree or branch, or clearing a `drive' that has missed. <i>(1913,Country Work,31</i>)

>  <b>KENWAY</b> Selecting a certain group of trees he will `belly scarf' and `back scarf' the lot ... If this `drive' as it is termed, has been well-managed the whole lot will came down together. <i>(1947,Quondam Quaker,53</i>)

>  <b>LEVY</b> ... from early morning till dark the axe would resound and the crash of falling trees, or drive of trees, would be the only sound ... <i>(1951,Grasslands of NZ,240,1970 ed.</i>)

>  <b>CRUMP</b> Jack learned about scarfing, backing, limbing, ... toms, strops, drives, triggers, ... <i>(1961,Hang on a Minute, Mate,42</i>)

>  <b>LYON</b> The bushmen developed an expert knowledge of driving, or directing one tree against another, or a body of trees, which swept a great weight in one irresistible drive of crashing and thunderous timber. <i>(1952,Faring South,179</i>)

>  <b>NEWTON</b> He had seen as many as twenty-four men in a single [professional bushfalling] gang and they worked `drives' of up to five acres and more [in the King Country]. <i>(1972,Wake of The Axe,117</i>)

>  <b>RICHARDS</b> It was quite a common practice for experienced bushmen, to have a `drive'. If you are chopping up a `face' and there is a large tree behind you further up the face, you select that as the `key'. To save time ... you do not waste time by chopping down each tree individually, but just `scarf' and partly chop each tree. When all is ready and you have worked back to the key, you scarf it verycarefully. ... If everything goes according to plan it will `drive' the one below, which will in turn drive the next, and so on ... <i>(1986,Off the Sheep's Back,22</i>)

>  <b>WILSON</b> A `drive' was in progress; as the men do the underscrubbing they note the large trees and their distance from each other. They scarf each one so that it will fall on the next. Then, after all the smaller timber has been brought down, they fell the first tree which falls on the second and so starts a whole sequence of crashes. The line need not be straight. More often, it zig-zags from right to left. Bushmen can do wonders by means of an ingenious drive. <i>(1955,Land of My Children,11</i>)



 
 <i>n.</i> [goldmining]

>  [quartz] Taking the claims as they came, the first ... consisted of a drive of about a hundred feet into a prominent looking `spur'. <i>(Oct 27, 1867,Trip to the Thames Gold-fields,27,1978 ed.</i>)

>  If he [sc. a mining manager] goes out in a buggy for a day hecharges it to the company as `putting in a fresh drive' <i>(1869,Wit and Humour: Local Songs...,31</i>) [NOTES: (Thatcher on Mining Companies)]

>  <b>BAINES</b> Our reef, or leader, measuring only four inches in thickness, a drive for a considerable distance following the course of the gold-bearing quartz had to be carried out, ... <i>(1874,Edward Crewe,262</i>)

>  <b>MONEY</b> ... the work was both difficult and dangerous, being a drive or tunnel made into the side of the hill, ... blasting the rocks that were too big ... <i>(1871,Knocking About in NZ,80</i>)
