The women use fans* there, the men use them here, Though to cockneys that statement may sound very queer, And the fellows that frequently hang round hotels, Out here are called loafers, at home are called swells. <i>Ibid.</i> [p 89 fn] * A fan is a machine for pumping air down the shafts. <i>(1875,NZ Songster,No.3/88</i>) [NOTES: London & the Diggings]

>  <b>LAPHAM</b> There was a deserted `drive' up on the spur. <i>(1880,We Four,18</i>)

These drives were called main levels. The bords were driven about two chains off the dip, and the `stenton' would be driven from the lower level to the one above. <i>(1928,Dawn Beloved,169</i>)

>  <b>BLYTH</b> Drive: A horizontal drift, or tunnel, in a mine. <i>(1935,Gold Mining Year Book,11</i>)

 <i>n.</i>

 <i>n.</i> [(axeman's) Compare punch @v. [nf discts.] =?]

 <i>n.</i> [[Can't find this at drive: check let.]]

 <i>n.</i> a mass of floating logs driven downstream. See v1. [(Northland kauri bushmen's)]

 <i>n.</i>

 <i>n.</i> a sheep or cattle-driver, a drover. cf drive @n and v&sup4.,

 <i>n.</i> a leather strap on the handle of a pair of shears, made to fit over the back of a shearer's hand.

 <i>n.</i> [[Poss. OMIT???]]

 <i>n.</i> [[check that this is not a miscopyng of drive].]

 <i>n.</i> a tree cut to push or `drive' others down

 <i>n.</i> [Poss. OMIT??]

## driver licence
 
 <i>n.</i> a state-issued authorisation to drive a vehicle [The British term is <i>driving licence</i>, which seems to be the one in general popular use in NZ.]



## driving
 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> [(Northland (kauri) bushman's)]

>  You have been in that district, about the creeks where the driving of the logs takes place? <i>(1896,AJHR,I.-4A/20</i>)

>  ... the `driving' of large kauri-logs in the creeks by `tripping' dams during flood-time ... [98??] ... Recently the creek-beds have been thoroughly scoured ... owing to the `driving' of kauri timber by lumbermen. <i>(1912,NZ Geol. Survey Bulletin,No.15 (N.S.) 34</i>) [NOTES: (Bell and Fraser, Waihi - Tairua)]



 
<b>2</b> <i>n.</i> [[?f. drive v2.]]

>  <b>EDMUND BOWLER</b> Hard work today driving (droving) owing to long grass. [The `droving' is Mayhew's insertion] <i>(Jan 1, 1858,Diary</i>) [NOTES: 1858 Jan 1 Edmund Bowler's Diary in 1949 Mayhew Tuapeka 12]

>  I wanted a [?] driving sheep, but he would not agree to that. <i>(1861,McLean Papers,20/8</i>) [NOTES: (Hawkes Bay)]

>  Pattison and I have the driving of 1500 Wethers from this run to town ... and I have the driving of a mob down and back ... in a few weeks I hope. <i>(Dec 2, 1864,Chudleigh Diary,155,1950 ed.</i>)

>  ... I had not time to call on Tripp ... so he has given his driving to O'Callaghan, a stranger instead of me. <i>(Feb 8, 1865,Chudleigh Diary,165,1950 ed.</i>)



 
<b>3</b> <i>n.</i>

>  <b>LEVY</b> Next, the forest trees up to approximately 30 in. in diameter were felled by a system of driving, the trees being notched on the upper and lower side of the drive, which commenced at the top of the slope and proceeded downwards. <i>(1951,Grasslands of NZ,241,1970 ed.</i>)

>  <b>LYON</b> The bushmen developed an expert knowledge of driving, or directing one tree against another, or a body of trees, which swept a great weight in one irresistible drive of crashing and thunderous timber. <i>(1952,Faring South,179</i>)



 
<b>4</b> <i>n.</i> [also driving-out]

>  Driving : The term used to describe the process of tunnelling. <i>(Sep 1999,Ohinemuri Regional History Journal,43 : 14</i>)

>  <b>EVANS</b> Immediately north of the [Waikaka] township a rich layer in the fault-involved older quartz drifts, ... was worked from the surface ... This layer is locally known as the `back lead'. On or near it a shaft was sunk ... but was not utilised for driving-out. <i>(1962,Waikaka Saga,4</i>) [NOTES: 1914 P.G. Morgan report Geological Survey Branch 147 in 1962 Evans Waikaka Saga 4]

>  <b>McARA</b> The term driving generally referred to tunnelling in any direction but in some circumstances, where reefs were present, it meant tunnelling along the line of the reef or parallel to it. The term drifting was used more specifically for driving on a reef, while the term crosscutting referred totunnelling across the reef up to an angle of say forty-five degrees; however it was common to talk of `driving a crosscut'. <i>(1978,Gold Mining at Waihi,184</i>)

 <i>n.</i>

NZA. <i>(1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,39</i>)

## drop
 
 <i>v.</i> Transf. f. an orig. reference to farm animals, esp. sheep, giving birth: cf. OED 14. [in various colloquial uses.]

>  The nannies should start dropping about 10th October. <i>(Sep 1986,Radio NZ / National Radio</i>) [NOTES: 1986 Sept Farming Programme, National Radio]



 
 <i>v.</i> In male informal use, to give birth to a baby (see also to drop one's bundle) (See [also drop one's bundle](../A#also-drop-one's-bundle))

Snigger, snigger. `She's not goin' to drop it,' said Nuts angrily. `It's goin' to be born.' `Same thing,' answered this know-all. `What do you know about babies, mate?' asked Nuts. <i>(1964,Any Old Dollars Mister?,71</i>)



 
 <i>v.</i> (Rural) to cut hay.

 <i>n.</i> (poison drop)

 <i>v.</i>

 <i>v.</i> to cut down, fell

## drop one's bundle
 
<b>1</b> <i>phr.</i> to give birth

>  <b>BALLANTYNE</b> If he doesn't hurry she'll be dropping her bundle at our place. <i>(1948,Cunninghams, The,25,1976 ed.</i>)

>  Suppose a friend says to me, `You know that drongo who was on the chain with me at the works last summer? Just a little joker he was, remember? A real serious ankle-biter. Hailed from somewhere down the Wire Wrapper. A right useless bastard. Couldn't see the road to the dunny if it had red flags on it. Well, it seems that he's shacked up with some pluty Remmers sheila and she's about to drop her bundle.' ... A non-New Zealander will probably require a translation, ... My friend is communicating to me the information that a slow-witted, incompetent person of diminutive stature, who was reared in the Wairarapa district and worked for a time in the killing gang of an abattoir, is now cohabiting with a wealthy woman from the affluent Auckland suburb of Remuera. This woman is soon to give birth. <i>(Jan 1989,Pacific Way,10</i>) [NOTES: (Sharp New Zildish)]



 
<b>2</b> <i>phr.</i> lose one's cool, panic

>  The fullback "dropped his bundle" completely. <i>(Sep 10, 1947,NZ Observer,27</i>)

>  <b>HAWES</b> 'Feefi's gonna drop his bundle, Dad, I can feel it.' <i>(2000,Dream of Nikau Jam, The,42</i>)

>  <b>PARTRIDGE</b> He absolutely dropped his bundle, and, to make matters worse, I had started off with a duck's breakfast, but I saw a cookhouse and decided to give it a pop for a binder. <i>(1935,Slang Today,287</i>)

>  <b>NEWTON</b> I found that once I left the security of my saddle and my reliable Jimmy, my confidence immediately disappeared. However, I could not drop my bundle, so into the jungle I went [after the ounded beast]. <i>(1947,Wayleggo,115,1949 ed.</i>)

>  <b>SCRYMGEOUR</b> From thence on Mabel [after losing the tennis set] began to drop her bundle, and as the crowd frantically applauded[,] the popular Nancy ... looked the part of a veritable `Venus'. Jim fought valiantly, served magnificently, ... but still Mabel wilted. <i>(1960,Memories of Maoriland,173</i>)

>  <b>SYDER & HODGETTS</b> To stop trying after experiencing a difficulty. .;`Come on! Cheer up! Don't drop your bundle. Look at it this way, it could ha' been a worse, now, couldn't it? Anyway, I've got some good news for you ...' <i>(1974,Australian & NZ English [TS],296</i>)

>  <i>bundle ... 7. drop one's bundle. Austral. sl.</i> to panic or give up hope. <i>(1982,Collins Concise English Dictionary,144</i>) [NOTES: [1986 NZPOD 94]]

>  <b>BEARDSLEY</b> drop his bundle become agitated <i>(1984,Blackball 08,243</i>)

>  <b>McGILL</b> <i>drop one's bundle </i> to despair or give birth; eg `Sam's dropped his bundle ever since that triple bogey on the 18th when he was four clear.' <i>(1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,40</i>)

<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) a tarpaulin or large sheet.

## dropper
 
 <i>n.</i> a light, vertical fence post between the main fixed posts, attached to the wires only to keep them firm and evenlyspaced.Contrast -->standard, -->waratah.

>  In the erection of a wire fence it isusual to put the posts in the ground at acomfortable distance apart, droppers beingused as intermediate attachments tothe wire to keep them from opening orcontracting so that animals are preventedfrom forcing their way between the wire. <i>(May 29, 1912,Otago Witness,33</i>)

>  She grabbed something between a dropper and a post and I a Koradi. <i>(Feb 26, 1927,NZ Dairy Produce Exporter,39</i>)

>  <b>HENDERSON</b> When all the wires are strained tightly the battens or droppers, which are split to about two inches square, are stapled at spaces varying from two to three feet. <i>(1965,Open Country,55</i>)

>  <b>Meredith</b> I ought to have mentioned that the first thing to do is to put in the `straining-posts,' and then run a wire ... to act as a line to erect posts by. ... Between the posts the wires are stapled to `droppers,' consisting of about three by one battens. <i>(1875,Adventuring in Maoriland in the Seventies,68,1935 ed.</i>)

>  All hands in the carpenters shop. Made a mess of cutting dropper slips. ... 14th. ... I made droppers all day. <i>(Jul 13, 1904,Chudleigh Diary,423,1950 ed.</i>)

>  DROPPER. Abbreviation of FENCE DROPPER; BATTEN <i>(1952,NZ Forest Glossary</i>)

>  <b>NEWTON</b> The `droppers' were first slung into place [on the pack-horse]. <i>(1949,High Country Days,39</i>)

>  The new [Heinemann's] dictionary carries: ... mall, ... M.O.W. and o.n.o. ... dropper (for fencing) ... and garage sale. <i>(Mar 28, 1979,Otago Daily Times,21</i>) [NOTES: (G. Griffiths)]

>  Dropper: Same as batten ... Used in parts of South Island and Australia. <i>(1982,MAF Agricultural Glossary,27</i>)

>  dropper ... NZ & Austral. batten in a fence. <i>(1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,230</i>) [NOTES: [nf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict.; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 148]]

>  <b>McGILL</b> dropper fence batten. NZA. <i>(1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,40</i>)

>  <b>LANCASTER</b> It was a viciously strained ten-wire, with close standards; and every other wire was a barb. Cosidy, who had prayed for slotted droppers, collapsed in the saddle. <i>(1904,Sons o' Men,93</i>) [NOTES: Check spelling of Cosidy]



 
 <i>n.</i> tubes which hang down and carry the milk, or pulsation tubes [(dairy-farming)]

>  Milking-machines: Droppers are the two small pipes to which the tubes with suction cups are attached. They hang or `drop' into the bail from the main pipeline. The operator is free to attend another bail while the cow is milking. <i>(1951,Personal Communication</i>) [NOTES: G.W. Turner]

>  Tubes which hang down and carry the milk, or pulsation tubes <i>(1982,MAF Agricultural Glossary,40</i>)



 
 <i>n.</i> (Rural) a batten on a flood-gate.

>  <b>SALISBURY</b> Afterwards it was quite simple to retie the sections back on the droppers. <i>(1994,I Was So Lucky,241</i>)



 
 <i>n.</i> the flexible worm which hangs down from above the shearer and carries the driving mechanism of the machine-shears. [??chk]

>  <b>BOWEN</b> ... when the comb digs in it makes the sheep kick and the dropper moves around and loses its true swing. <i>(1955,Wool Away!,4</i>)



 
 <i>n.</i> Cf pikau, pocket @n. [(station, high-country farming)]

>  <b>NEWTON</b> Potatoes and vegetables were in sacks known as `droppers' which would hang from the hooks on each side of the pack saddles. <i>(1949,High Country Days,38</i>)



 
 <i>n.</i> One who delivers sly-grog supplies in a dry district, either by lorry or from a train; a sly-grog wholesaler [(obs.) ca1920 at least: probably earlier, P.S. Arden]

>  <b>EDMOND</b> A dropper is a person who sells sly grog. They were called droppers up there [in Ohakune, a dry district]. <i>(1992,Autobiography of My Father,69</i>)

>  <b>SARGESON</b> She does catering, he said. And she sells it. You know what I mean, Dave - sly grog. One time when the police raided her she was doing the washing, Johnny said. And they reckoned they'd got her this time, because they'd found out a dropper had been through the town just a few nights before on his lorry. So they reckoned she'd be well stocked up. <i>Ibid.</i> 255 [The police] reckon they'd got her [slygrogging] this time, because they'd found out a dropper had been through the town just a few nights before on his lorry. <i>(1949,I Saw in My Dream,247,(1974 ed Rhodes) ed.</i>)

>  A gang of the boys often beat up the local `dropper' in Raurimu, who can't say anything or else he'll get had up for `dropping.' The police usually allow only one `dropper' in the town and clamp down on the others. <i>(1952,Personal Communication</i>) [NOTES: (? informant: King Country)]

>  <b>McCLENAGHAN</b> ... They could bring in their own liquor ... and there was no reason [20] why they should when they could rely on the droppers. <i>(1976,Travelling Man,19</i>)

>  <b>EDMOND</b> ... there was [ca1950s] a chap called Paddy the Pig, a dropper ... he told him he had to pay [pounds] 5 for the last inch in a bottle of whiskey. <i>(1984,High Country Weather,22</i>)

>  The man who enters a bording(?) or `temperance' house is immediately accused of having rolled a beer barrel through the maze of the Licensing Act. He is suspected of designs of all descriptions. He is dubbed `a dropper', or `blind tiger.' <i>(Oct 26, 1912,NZ Truth,383/6/5</i>)

>  We want [pounds] 2 a week extra for the `looker-out' and the `dropper.' <i>(Apr 5, 1951,Dominion</i>) [NOTES: [Arbitration Court evidence] [Hotelworkers]]

>  <b>MORRIESON</b> ... have a swig for Christmas ... A man isn't a big time dropper for nothing. <i>(1974,Predicament,61,1981 ed.</i>)

>  A person who sells or hands over sly-grog, or afterhours grog: there was an article in Christchurch ?Star-Sun ?ca1946-7 `Spotters and Droppers' <i>(1972,Personal Communication</i>) [NOTES: ca1972 p.c. Jack Columbus (Blenheim)]



 
 <i>n.</i> (Rural) a tube carrying a driveshaft that powers a shearing handpiece.

>  <b>BOWEN</b> A shearer will shear less sheep in a day if he is cutting them, as when the comb digs in it makes the sheep kick and the dropper moves around. <i>(1955,Wool Away!,4</i>)

>  <b>RICHARDS</b> I now have a collection of antiques .. old handpieces, combs, cutters, droppers. <i>(1989,Pioneer's Life, A,41</i>)



 
 <i>n.</i> (Rural) a part of a milking system.

>  The droppers are very free-swinging and follow whatever position the milker moves into with the cups ... young cows can crowd up along the line and get out of position with the dropper. <i>(Dec 31, 1964,NZ Farmer,10</i>)

>  Each claw has its own pulsation system so that it's no longer necessary to have a separate air line and separate droppers to each cluster. <i>(Nov 1975,NZ Farmer,13</i>)

>  <b>MAF</b> Droppers: Tubes which hang down and cary the milk or pulsation tubes. <i>(1982,MAF Agricultural Glossary,40</i>)

>  Your complete conversion pack includes rubber bends, new milk and air tubes and droppers. <i>(Mar 1987,NZ Dairy Exporter,36</i>)



 
 <i>n.</i> (Rural) a large bag, billy or pot on a packsaddle.

>  <b>LOUGHNAN</b> dropper: open-mouthed pannier for loose goods such as carrots, potatoes etc which hangs on the side of a pack saddle. <i>(1981,Loughnan Glossary,27</i>)



 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) [mainly S. I.] a fence batten.

>  <b>MEREDITH</b> Between the posts the wires are stapled to 'droppers' consisting of about three by one battens. <i>(1875,Adventuring in Maoriland in the Seventies,68</i>) [NOTES: (1935)]

>  After sheep dipping, the dip is used for soaking the droppers in. These droppers, or battens, to which the wires are nailed between the strainer ... <i>(Aug 1900,NZ Farmer,331</i>)

>  The cheapest and most expensive dropper in the market. A perfect stay and post saver. <i>(Mar 9, 1907,Farmers' Union Advocate,15</i>)

>  <b>RIDDOLLS</b> .. no stapling is used, and each wire runs freely through all posts and droppers without risk of kinking. <i>(1958,Farm Engineering,428</i>)

>  <b>DU FAUR</b> Battens, or droppers, are also expensive components of the traditional fence ... <i>(1966,Sheep Farming for Profit,192</i>)

>  <b>STACEY</b> Once the wires were strained and stapled it had the distinction of being the only properly constructed wire fence in the valley with rimu droppers perfectly spaced. <i>(1996,Tales of a Tussock Jumper,42</i>)

>  <b>FISK</b> Ask a Northlander to throw you a dropper and you are likely to get a fist in your mush, while in the South Island a batten is what you do down to the hatches when the nor'wester starts blowing. <i>(1996,Practical Smallfarming,7</i>)

>  So I planted a dropper, a 2" x 2" of Black pine about three feet long under the dropping bench. <i>(2001,Good Bastards: the larrikin's guide to success,263</i>)



 
<b>2</b> <i>n.</i> a hotel worker who handed out illegal after-hour take-away liquor; a sly-grog scout. [(to ?1968)]

>  It is possible to get as much liquor as one wants in Masterton, and while much of it (privately and legitimately brought in) is of good quality, much more (surreptitiously dispensed at sly-groggeries and by what are locally termed `droppers' at enhanced prices) is atrocious and harmful liquor. ...A Masterton gentleman ... told our representative that the knew of twenty sly-groggeries in Masterton, and double that number of `droppers.' It can be imagined what kind of poison they dispense. <i>(Oct 28, 1911,NZ Truth,331/4/6</i>)

## drove
 
 <i>n.</i> The word is in use in NZ, but earlier drive (q.v.) would poss. be preferred.] [?More cits or omit or have one entry at verb.???]

 <i>n.</i> Pa. tense droved; =drive (travelling stock).

Witness: `He's a bush feller.' <i>(Apr 23, 1910,NZ Truth,252/1/6</i>)

But the name Borderwas never heard of until after 1900 when it came to denote an area [Scottish or English] in which a series of sheepdog trials were held ... <i>(1985,Working Dogs,7</i>)



 
 <i>v.</i> (Rural) to drive farm stock on hoof.

## drummer
 
 <i>n.</i>

>  KYPHOSUS SYDNEYANUS Gunther. <i>Drummer</i>. ... Distribution: North Island coasts. <i>(Jun 1921,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,IV/16</i>)

>  <b>PARROTT</b> THE DRUMMER <i>Kyphosus sydneyanus<</i> (Gunther) <i>(1957,Sea Anglers' Fishes of NZ,101</i>)

>  <b>GRAHAM</b> Drummer <i>Segutilum sydneyanum</i> (Gunther) (Syn. <i>Pachymetopon</i> and <i>Pimelepterus drewii</i> Hector) <i>(1956,NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide,407</i>) [NOTES: 1955 Whitley Namelist in 1956 Graham NZ Fishes 407]

>  <b>WILSON</b> DRUMMER Inhabitant of more northern, rocky waters down to about 100 feet (30.48 metres) the Drummer, or Silver Drummer as he is sometimes known, is characterised by his stout shape and small mouth and head. <i>(1981,Fisherman's Bible,60</i>)

>  <b>MORELAND</b> DRUMMER [<i>Kyphosus sydneyanus<</i>] ... Silver drummer is an alternative name. <i>(1967,Marine Fishes,42</i>)

>  <b>DOOGUE & MORELAND</b> DRUMMER ... <i>Other names: Kyphosus sydneyanus</i>; silver drummer. <i>(1966,Sea Anglers' Guide,240</i>)

>  <b>NATUSCH</b> Family KYPHOSIDAE. We have just one kyphosid, the oval drummer, <i>Kyphosus sydneyanus</i>..., a small-mouthed fish with small soft scales covering head, body and fins; it has an outer row of cutting teeth and fine teeth on the jaws and roof of the mouth (vomer). About thirty inches long, ... <i>(1967,Animals of NZ, The,221</i>)

>  <i>drummer ... NZ & Austral. </i>... NZ greyish-green oval fish. <i>(1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,231</i>) [NOTES: [nf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict.]]

>  <b>PAUL et al.</b> [index to common names 283-293] drummer 1505-14 DRUMMERS 1491-1523 <i>(1987,Fishes: A Bibliography</i>)



 
 <i>n.</i> the slowest (often the learner) shearer in a gang [(station)]

>  The `drummer,' starting from the man who carried a drum, became the man who carried a swag and (then or thereafter) the loaded man (as a commercial traveller loaded with samples). To `carry the load' is another synonym; and the essential point throughout the symbolry was evidently the load. ... and a `drummer' is the man with the lowest tally - perhaps because he is likeliest to take and keep the track with his `load.' The general applications of these fresh significations may be doubted. <i>(Jul 7, 1911,Maoriland Worker,18/14/2</i>)

>  Drummer.-The slowest shearer in a shed. <i>(Jan 20, 1934,Press, The,15</i>)

>  <b>NEWTON</b> Hewett, the learner, and `' of the gang with seventeen to his credit had also shown an improvement. <i>(1949,High Country Days,55</i>)

>  <b>PARTRIDGE</b> Drummer. 8. Slowest shearer in a shed: New Zealand shearers': since ca. 1890. Niall Alexander letter of Oct. 22, 1939. Perhaps ex sense 1. <i>(1949,Dictionary of Slang Addenda,1037</i>)

>  RINGER. The fastest shearer in the gang. Fast men are also known as `guns,' and the slowest man in the shed as the `drummer.' <i>(1949,High Country Days,197,1950 ed.</i>)

>  <b>ACLAND</b> Drummer: The slowest shearer in a shed. <i>(1951,Early Canterbury Runs,366</i>)

>  <b>MEEK</b> DRUMMER: The shearer with the lowest aggregate tally of shorn sheep. <i>(1952,Station Days in Maoriland,110</i>)

>  <b>BOWEN</b> DRUMMER. The slowest shearer on the board. He shears at the bottom of the board, the furthest away from the wool table. <i>(1956,Wool Away!,156</i>)

>  <b>MASTERS</b> ... I was only the drummer (slowest shearer) of that particular gang, ... [1925 - North Canterbury] <i>(1960,Back-Country Tales,255</i>)

>  Drummer: Slowest shearer on the board who shears at the bottom of the board furthest away from the wool table. <i>(1982,MAF Agricultural Glossary,54</i>)

>  <b>RICHARDS</b> Fred, being the ganger, was on No. 1 stand. Mick was No. 2, Thornton No. 3, and I, being a learner, was on the traditional `drummer's' stand, at the far end of the board. <i>(1986,Off the Sheep's Back,73</i>)

>  drummer: The name given to the shearer with the lowest daily tally. He is not necessarily a bad or lazy shearer, but simply slower than the rest, and in a group of good shearers he could be quite competent, but not as good as the others. <i>(1989,NZ English Newsletter,3/24</i>) [NOTES: (Wallace Shearing Glossary)]

<b>2</b> <i>n.</i>

## dry
 
 <i>adj.</i> of a claim or workings, removed from water; occas., not liable to flooding or seepage. See also dry diggings.

>  The account of the Gully which he gives is, that fair prospects have been found there, and his opinion is that a party can make an ounce a man, as the sinking is very shallow, and the working dry. <i>(Sep 20, 1861,NZ Goldfields,13</i>) [NOTES: 1861 Sep 20 in NZ Goldfields 1861 (1976) 13]



 
 <i>adj.</i> (with respect to alcohol) [Jim Cameron writes: NSOD gives the general sense, but the words (dry area) and several compounds have considerable historic significance in NZ from the 1890s almost up to the the present. DNZE does not record these - wet/dry area, district, vote; go wet, stay dry. NZPOD has no entry for wet in this sense but does for dry.]

>  [Caption] In the early days of its history the Corbans winery was located in a 'dry' electorate; the small white building in the background, situated across the railway lines in a 'wet' area was used for many years as the company's sale depot. <i>(Jun 1991,Cuisine,83</i>)

>  Mr Halford remembers when there was a post office, six churches, three hotels, three garages, two grocers, two tearooms, blacksmiths and wheelwrights, a bakery, bank, drapery, hardware, watchmaker and a town hall, where the ladies smuggled in liquor to the dances under their wide skirts in the days when the district was "dry". <i>(Jan 5, 2002,Dominion Weekend Magazine,1</i>)

>  This is a "dry" town with no licensed hotels. <i>(Mar 3, 1938,NZ Observer,7</i>)

>  John says they considered turning it into a restaurant because it is so far up the hill it is just outside the Tawa boundary - and therefore out of the "dry" liquor area. Tawa was a dry area until it went wet following the election. <i>(Jan 13, 2000,Evening Post,11</i>)

>  The hotel was closed when the district went "dry" in 1906, the bar reopening for business in 1998. <i>(Jun 2004,NZ Memories,No. 48/41</i>)

>  Paeroa is "dry". <i>(Sep 20, 1913,NZ Observer,4</i>)

>  From that date [1906] the town was legally "dry". <i>(1944,Korero (AEWS Background Bulletin),2(17) : 3</i>)

>  <b>HUTT</b> The east coast remained 'dry' until 1922 when special enabling legislation made a second poll possible. <i>(1999,Maori & Alcohol,67</i>)

>  Prior to the last general election Tawa was one of the only three dry suburbs in New Zealand. <i>(Oct 4, 2000,Capital Times,17</i>)

>  In 1864 came the proclamation that made the first part of the King Country - the Te Kuiti, Otorohanga and Kawhia districts - "dry". <i>(Sep 23, 1953,NZ Observer,6</i>)

>  The Horouta district went "dry" in 1911. <i>(Dec 14, 1922,Auckland Weekly News,23</i>)

>  It is said.. that in some "dry" places they will get up a smoke concert to celebrate a fellow having got over a severe stomach ache. <i>(Jan 8, 1910,NZ Truth,4</i>)

## dry diggings
 
 <i>n.</i>

>  <b>HOCHSTETTER</b> The conglomerates accumulated on the slopes of the mountains are the proper field for the "dry diggings", while from the gravel and sand streams the gold is obtained by "wet diggings". <i>(1867,New Zealand (Hochstetter),104</i>)

>  <b>HOCHSTETTER & PETERMAN</b> By the gradual wearing away of these rocks ... large masses of debris have been formed, and nature itself has executed an operation of gold-washing, by collecting the heavier particles and depositing them in the gullies of streams, or in the conglomerates covering the slopes of the hills. There are, therefore, two principal descriptions of diggings; either `river diggings', in the beds of streams, or `dry diggings', in the conglomerate and gravel accumulated on the slopes of the mountains. <i>(1864,Geology NZ,88</i>)

>  The milk sugar should be got rid of as quickly as possible when time came for drying the cow off and this was best accomplished by completing the drying-off in the minimum time. ## Dry Valley
 
 <i>n.</i>

He was [87 years old.] Dr Dye was born in Driffield, Yorkshire, and educated at Bridlington School and Leeds University from which he graduated in 1925 as a Doctor of Science. He came to New Zealand in 1929 to be a lecturer at the newly-founded Massey Agricultural College. Shortly after his arrival Dr Dry discovered a ram lamb in a flock near Palmerston North which had an extremely hairy fleece due to an abundance of halo-hairs. Dr Dry's successful efforts to isolate the gene in Romney led to the development of the Drysdale. Dr Dry devoted nearly 40 years studying the genetic makeup of the fleece of the sheep and published many papers. ## duck
 
 <i>n.</i> [[Check ca1899 1957 Pascoe MED 235/7 [Birds South Westland] See also parera, putangitangi, whio]

>  Sea and water fowles of all sorts are however in no great plenty, those known in Europe are Ducks, Shags, Gannets and gulls all of which were eat(?) by us and found exceeding good, ... <i>(Mar 31, 1770,Cook's Journals,1/276,1955 ed.</i>)

>  <b>PARKER</b> `There are eleven species of Native Ducks belonging to nine genera, all found elsewhere, except two--the little Flightless Duck of the Auckland Islands (genus <i>Nesonetta</i>) and the Blue Mountain Duck (<i>Hymenolaemus</i>). Among the most interesting of the non-endemic forms, are the Paradise Duck or Sheldrake (<i>Casarca variegata</i>), the Brown Duck (<i>Anas chlorotis</i>), the Shoveller or Spoonbill duck (<i>Rhynchaspis variegata</i>), and the Scaup or Black Teal (<i>Fuligula Novae-Zealandiae</i>).'] <i>(1889,Catalogue NZ Exhibition,117</i>) [NOTES: [Morris]]



 
<b>2</b> <i>n.</i> Early, of various native spp.; now, also introduced spp., ?esp. the mallard gen sp

>  <b>FORSTER</b> In this fine place, we found a number of wild fowl, and particularly wild ducks ... from whence we gave it the name of Duck Cove. <i>(1777,Voyage Round the World,1/137</i>)

>  <b>MARSDEN</b> ... we dined off a wild duck and potatoes, as also some provisions we had brought with us. The duck Shunghee shot at the lake. <i>(1815,Letters & Journals,99,1932 ed.</i>)

>  <b>CRAIK</b> Among them are many sorts of wild ducks, large wood-pigeons, sea gulls, rails, parrots, and parroquets. <i>(1830,New Zealanders, The,187</i>)

>  The River `Wiiaw' is very spacious in places, ... and abounds in fish, eels and wild-ducks of 3 or 4 different kinds. <i>(1835,Boultbee Journal,74,1986 ed.</i>)

>  I found [round Wellington] Teal, common Wild Duck, the paradise Duck, a variety of the Grebe, a kind of Water Hen the proper name of which I do not know. <i>(Jun 1840,Boultbee Journal,230,1966 ed.</i>)

>  We scarcely took a step that did not delight us; the soil good, the banks of the [Waipa] river high, interspersed with woods of kahikatea. ... Here the banks of the river were covered with wild-ducks. <i>(1842,GBPP,(No.569) 98</i>) [NOTES: 1841 Jan 4 Report of George Clarke, Protector of Aborigines in GBPP 1842 (No.569) 98]

>  <b>WAKEFIELD</b> These (wild ducks of different sorts) are principally the black, the grey, the blue-winged, and the paradise duck, or `pa tangi tangi', as it is called by the natives. The last is nearly as large as a goose, and of beautiful plumage <i>(1845,Adventure in NZ,1/57</i>)

>  Wild ducks, called `Paradise Ducks', nearly as large as a Goose, splendid eating. <i>(1848,Otago Journal,3/47</i>) [NOTES: (R. Donaldson)]

>  <b>POWER</b> A few curlews, whale-birds, sand-pipers, and wild ducks frequent the coast and river swamps, but are generally fishy, and unfit for the table. <i>(1849,Sketches in NZ,72</i>)

>  <b>1/80</b> [The Waikato] runs through ... deep fern fringed with raupo (a bullrush) ...[sic] and the magnificent toi-toi, a gigantic grass whose flower stalk is from 8 to 12 feet and has an exquisite feather of two feet long playing in every air. This grass is ... with the phormium tenax the most remarkable of the open country vegetable products. ... You see many nativedwellings & many canoes for they are a most locomotive people, few as ignorant of all but their own kainga as our British Hodge. There are troops of wild ducks & shags, some hawks of large size, bitterns & smaller waterfowl unknown to me. <i>(Mar 25, 1851,Richmond-Atkinson Papers,1960</i>) [NOTES: (J.C. Richmond)]

>  <b>KENNAWAY</b> ... our delicate ... stomachs received the most racy and highly esteemed dainties peculiar to the cuddy table, and which when you all come out you will soon discover, such as `Duff & Treacle', Boiled Pudding, Plum Duff, ... and bread in particular. <i>(1851,Biscuit and Butter,78,1973 ed.</i>)

>  <b>PHILLIPS</b> I. left at home with strict injunctions to make a duff - <i>(Sep 8, 1867,Journal Kept at Rockwood and the Point,115</i>)

>  <b>HODDER</b> I chopped suet and plums to make a `duff' for dinner. <i>(1862,Memories of NZ Life,10</i>)

>  We had a plum duff boiling. <i>(1959,Early Travellers,393</i>) [NOTES: 1864 Barrington West Coast Prosp Party in 1959 Taylor Early Travelles 393]

>  <b>BAKER</b> ... `duff' - that's colonial for pudding, ma'am. <i>(1872,Xmas Cake in Four Quarters, A,Chap III</i>)

>  <b>TONKIN</b> On Christmas Day ... if they [Dunedin gaol prisoners] do not absolutely have plum pudding they have a plain of [sic] `duff', with a few currants in it, which to them is doubtless as acceptable as the richest of plum puddings <i>(1980,Dunedin Gaol,15</i>) [NOTES: >c1875 Otago Guardian in 1980 Tonkin Dunedin Gaol 15]

>  <b>DUNCAN</b> If we drew their attentions to ... the inevitable currant pudding on Sunday, their only answer was `Take the whole blooming `duff.' <i>(1888,Wakatipians,28</i>)

>  <b>BROOKES</b> The largest duff I have ever seen ... <i>(1892,Frontier Life,111</i>)

>  <b>CARR</b> Anyone who can bake, make a decent `brownie' (as the plain cake is called) and a plum duff is fit for a shearers' cook. <i>(1913,Country Work,17</i>)

>  Duff: A very plain plum pudding, which was the invariable second course at Sunday dinner on stations. (G.P.W.) [A Northern English variant of,`dough' not recorded before the nine-teeth century.--A.W.] <i>(Oct 14, 1933,Press, The,15</i>) [NOTES: (Acland Gloss.)]

>  <b>HYDE</b> The duff boiled for three hours, and the rattle of tin plates was a newly invented song of the flax-cutters. <i>(1936,Passport to Hell,48</i>)

>  <b>HENDERSON</b> Take P.O.W. for example. Everyone had bashed up a duff for himself at one stage or another. <i>(1945,Gunner Inglorious,140</i>)

>  <b>NEWTON</b> Duff - `steamed pudding' <i>(1947,Wayleggo</i>) [NOTES: Gloss]

>  <b>NEWTON</b> <i>(1949,High Country Days,195,1950 ed.</i>) [NOTES: (Gloss.)]

>  <b>OGONOWSKA-COATES</b> Duff. A plain boiled pudding that was standard fare for shearers in the early days. <i>(1987,Boards, Blades & Barebellies,96</i>)

>  <b>FRANCIS</b> The [station] midday meal was more often a cut lunch eaten on the job. The main meal, `tea', was basically mutton, potatoes, onions, ... and, for afters, stewed dried fruit, plum duff or riceand prunes. <i>(1983,Wildlife Ranger,2</i>)

>  Who will race to Divvy Base and fetch a Christmas duff? <i>(Dec 22, 1941,NZEF Times,I/26 : 17</i>)



 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) a steamed pudding renowned of station cooks and packies.

>  <b>MONEY</b> The duff was made, the potatoes were boiled .. with plenty of sow thistles or Maori cabbage to give it a flavour ... <i>(1871,Knocking About in NZ,68</i>)

>  <b>WILLIAMS</b> This is Sunday, a fact I'm made strongly to feel, By the presence of duff at our middle-day meal. <i>(1889,Colonial Couplets,9</i>)

>  The soil appears fairly good but here and there a few stones are visible, not very many, but scattered all through like the plums in some station duffs. <i>(1894,NZ Farmer,52</i>)

>  The packer, who is in charge of the packhorses, acts as camp cook. In the evening there is a huge meal, with a 'duff' if the packer has had time to build one. <i>(Aug 1, 1936,NZ Dairy Exporter,69</i>)

>  A good 'duff' is good indeed and a slice kept for lunch next day is a very sustaining food on the hill but a bad duff is terrible. <i>(Oct 27, 1938,NZ Farmer,10</i>)

>  <b>MCLEOD</b> .. the packie gets to work on a full-scale dinner of mutton, spuds, vegetables and duff ... <i>(1951,NZ High Country,32</i>)

>  <b>HILL</b> Jack [the station cook] was soaking his feet in the dish that he mixed the duffs in! <i>(1990,Between the Rivers,192</i>)

>  <b>ANDERSON</b> Jack was a wonderful cook and made the best station duff. [station duff] <i>(1966,Over the River,204</i>)



## duff (up)
 
 <i>v.</i> to make pregnant

>  <b>MORRIESON</b> He duffed one of the maids up at his old man's house and she died having an abortion, ... <i>(1974,Predicament,72,1981 ed.</i>)

>  <b>MAUGHAM</b> Still he had changed all that, moving into practice and duffing Elizabeth. <i>(1975,Good and Faithful Servants,7</i>)

>  <b>JOHNSTON</b> When Ma-Mac finds out I've duffed her daughter there'll be a bloody massacre in the village! <i>(1981,Fish Factory,65</i>)

## duffer
 
 <i>adj.</i> . [goldmining]

>  <b>WAITE</b> Those first disappointed arrivals chose to call the expedition a duffer rush. <i>(1869,Discovery West Coast Goldfields,15</i>)

>  ... more than ordinarily rich the last six months seems to have been in `duffer rushes.' <i>(1870,AJHR,D-40-4</i>) [NOTES: Report Goldfields West Coast and Auckland]

>  <b>WHITWORTH</b> ... you remember the duffer rush at Bruce Bay ... <i>(1875,Cobb's Box,8</i>)

>  <b>MAY</b> Duffer rushes collapsed so quickly that storekeepers could find themselves in the back-of-beyond with a fully-stocked shanty and no sales to pay for the cost of packing-in and packing-out. <i>(1962,West Coast Gold Rushes,281,1967 ed.</i>)

>  <b>PFAFF</b> He was among the earliest at Hokitika, Grey, ... Jackson's Bay (a duffer's rush), etc. <i>(1914,Diggers' Story, The,151</i>)



 
 <i>n.</i>

>  If the cows are themselves duffers, and are mated to a mongrel bull, the heifer calves cannot turn our very good ... <i>(1902,Brett's Colonists Guide,28</i>)

>  The following tables very well illustrate the value of culling out those cows that the system of testing reveals to be `duffers.' <i>(Jan 15, 1912,NZ Journal of Agriculture,382</i>)

>  <b>POWDRELL</b> Practical farmers sometimes put two calves on to one duffer cow, or to a run cow for five or six weeks ... <i>Ibid.</i> 45 ... first he must weed out the `duffers' ... <i>(1920,Dairy Farming in NZ,42</i>)



 
 <i>n.</i>

>  <b>MAY</b> Another duffer of a different kind took place in July. Vague reports that the Commercial Banking Company and the New Zealand Banking Corporation had suspended payments caused a run on the unsuspecting Bank of New Zealand at Okarito township, and also at the Ross. <i>(1962,West Coast Gold Rushes,186,1967 ed.</i>)



 
 <i>n.</i> [goldmining]

>  <b>PFAFF</b> I sunk a shaft on the Larrikin's Terrace there, but it proved a duffer. <i>(1914,Diggers' Story, The,56</i>)

>  All hands.. are gone or going to theCreek.. which has often been pronounced"a duffer". Here.. a party got into a"pot-hole" and had got for two days' worksixteen ounces of gold. <i>(Mar 4, 1869,Westport Times,2</i>)

>  New rushes are spoken of every day, and the township which has sprung up is full of life and excitement caused by the crowds of diggers, packers, and storekeepers, all anxiously awaiting the latest intelligence to be off for "pastures new" on the Golden Grey. Affairs will not take their usual course if we do not have numbers coming back to the Hokitika, loudly declaring the whole thing a "duffer"and a "sell." <i>(Aug 3, 1865,Evening Post,2</i>)

>  They turned out a lot of "duffers". <i>(May 3, 1879,Auckland Weekly News,19</i>)

>  I think I should have preferred the old claim at the Thames, duffer as it was. <i>(Jan 1, 1887,Auckland Weekly News,7</i>)

>  The verdict of the miners ... regarding the Taieri rush is this, `that it is, as a gold-diggings, essentially a `duffer.' <i>(1864,Saturday Review,50</i>)

>  <b>MONEY</b> ... our claim proved a `duffer'. No less than fifteen shafts did we sink ..., but found a prospect of nothing sufficient to encourage us in working it. <i>Ibid.</i> 121 [Prospective diggers] had only arrived to find the whole thing what is called in digging parlance a `duffer' - i.e., that there was comparatively `nothing' to repay them for even the trouble of digging a single hole. <i>(1871,Knocking About in NZ,99</i>)

>  <b>WRIGHT</b> He was working like a nigger, sinking duffers here and there. <i>(1897,Station Ballads,19</i>) [NOTES: [`Prospector']]

>  <b>VON HAAST</b> This visit was commemorated by miners who took up `Hochstetter' and `Haast' claims, which, as we have seen, unlike their namesakes, proved `duffers'. <i>(1948,Julius Von Haast,26 fn</i>)

>  duffer 1. Useless or stupid person. 2. In Australia and New Zealand, a worked-out orunprofitable mine. <i>(1958,Whitcombe's Modern Junior Dictionary (8th edn),133,8th ed.</i>)

>  <b>MAY</b> DUFFER: applied to a rush, a shaft, or a claim generally. A failure. Synonyms were `shicer',`stringer' or, in the case of a false rush, `store-keepers' rush'. A claim which was exhausted was said to be `duffered out'. At Ross in 1866 putting down a duffer shaft was termed `sinking for the Queen'. Duffers (Creek) is a common West Coast place-name. <i>(1962,West Coast Gold Rushes,526,1967 ed.</i>)

>  <b>HAY</b> A duffer: No gold. ...CLAIMS Worthless claims or ground were called schicers or duffers. Those yielding up to [pounds]3 per week per man were known as `tucker' claims; up to [pounds]8 per week were known as `wages' claims; above [pounds]8 were known as `pilers'; the richest of all were known as `Home-ward-bounders.' <i>(1974,Bright Fine Gold,200</i>) [NOTES: (Glossary of Mining Terms)]

>  <b>NOLAN</b> Duffer: a mine, claim or gold-rush which proves worthless. <i>(1983,Gold Fossicker's Handbook,112</i>) [NOTES: (gloss)]

>  duffer ... 3. Austral. sl. a. a mine that proves unproductive. b. a person who steals cattle. <i>(1982,Collins Concise English Dictionary,344</i>) [NOTES: [1986 NZPOD 232]]

>  ... the place was `rushed' by about 500 men, who speedily deserted it, and declared the Waitahuna to be a `duffer.' <i>(1863,AJHR,D6-3</i>) [NOTES: also in 1887 Handbook NZ Mines 5]

>  <b>HOPEFUL</b> If a man isn't `up to the mark' he is called `a regular shicer!' This phrase originated from the gold diggings. Supposing a man is digging, but without success, andhe therefore abandons his hole, it is called a `shicer' - that is, the ground was called a `shicer' or duffer, thus the origin. <i>(1887,Taken In,135</i>)

>  <b>BLAIR</b> He puddled and cradled, and digged all he knew / When the claim proved a regular duffer. <i>(1889,Lay of the Old Identities, The,48</i>)

>  It was soon found to be a "duffer" rush. <i>(Nov 11, 1924,Otago Witness,66</i>)



 
<b>2</b> <i>v.</i> a washout

>  ... declaring the whole thing a `duffer' and a `sell.' <i>(1865,Evening Post,1/152/2</i>)

 <i>v.</i>

## dummy
 
 <i>n.</i> solitary confinement [Compare boob, cooler, digger. ca1941 Prison slang: Riverside Community]

>  Down below.. is the solitary block. This is the dreaded "dummy" where the prison J.P. sends recalcitrants for a spell on bread and water. <i>(Jan 15, 1947,NZ Observer,9</i>)

>  He [sc. Paddy Webb] described the punishment known as "dummy" - solitary confinement in a dark cell on hard rations. He had seen men go into "dummy" in fairly good health and come out physical wrecks. In "dummy" they got three small blankets, and had to sleep on the floor. <i>(Jul 31, 1917,Press, The,8</i>)

>  Mr Webb added that if he had been found out in this dishonest behaviour, he would have been put in the 'dummy' - solitary confinement. <i>(Aug 14, 1917,Wanganui Herald,4</i>)

>  The young prisoner [in the Terrace Gaol] got so bad with boils that he was unable to work, and was placed in `The Dummy,' a building which the prisoner described to `Truth' as an old chicken house. Whilst in `The Dummy' he received no attention whatever, except that his meals were brought to him. <i>(Jun 5, 1909,NZ Truth,206/5/5</i>)

>  <b>HYDE</b> He was taken before the Governor and sentenced to three days in the Dummy. It is always dusk in the Dummy, which lies underground. ... At six in the morning the door is unlocked, and the prisoner gets his clothes, all except boots. <i>(1936,Passport to Hell,62</i>)

>  <b>BURTON</b> The aggressor in this case was promptly led off and incarcerated in the `dummy' [for attacking a warder]. <i>Ibid.</i> 109 Someone else had seen a bloodstained towel coming from the `dummy'. <i>(1952,In Prison,107</i>)

>  <b>LEE</b> When one of the prisoners was put in the dummy for misbehaviour, Jim O'Brien ... wanted to bring the jail out on strike. <i>(1965,Rhetoric at the Red Dawn,127</i>)

>  <b>McKENZIE</b> The punishment block, known as the `pound' or the `dummy', was a prison within the [Mt Eden] prison. In the basement, through a steel grille and a wooden door, it was a dimly lit and silent annexe leading at its far end to the tiny execution yard. <i>Ibid.</i> 96 dummy punishment block. See pound and back <i>(1980,While We Have Prisons,14</i>)

>  <b>NEWBOLD</b> Dummy. (n) Detention unit. <i>(1982,Big Huey, The,248</i>)

>  Though some of the [prison] conditions ... have changed - in that prisons have become more hygienic, bread and water is no longer the basic diet in dummy, nor is the Bible the only punishment book - ... the isolation of solitary confinement still has the whiff of the oubliette. <i>(Oct 13, 1984,Listener (New Zealand Listener),47</i>)

>  <b>McGILL</b> dummy punishment cell in prison. - practice of taking up land allegedly for yourself, but onbehalf of another, usually a friend or relative acting for a squatter. NZA. <i>(1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,41</i>)



 
 <i>n.</i> [(Mount Eden prison).]

>  They took him down to the dummy yard where the flogging framework was set up and, Joe said, half the senior staff in The Hill was there. <i>(Nov 1950,Here & Now,15</i>)



 
 <i>n.</i> In NZ from the time land laws were applied, one paid to acquire the title to a parcel of Crown land on behalf of another who was not legally entitled to do so; one who acquires title to land in name only, on behalf of another.

>  Mr. Browning held the shares in question.. and transferred them to Mr. Martin Sholl, sharebroker, who transferred them to William Lestrange, a well-known "dummy." <i>(Apr 26, 1873,Auckland Weekly News</i>)

>  <b>TREGEAR</b> He can go and be a Dummy on the Otago runs. <i>(1884,Southern Parables,17</i>)

>  <b>WRIGHT</b> And yet the talk is evermore, `The people want the land!'/ .../ The greedy few will clamour loud and clamour to the end;/ A dummy grabbing what he can is not the people's friend./ And Heaven's curse is on him still in all his schemes for gain;/ ... <i>Ibid.</i> 58 It's the pig-shooting dummy I've `set',/ And I'm willing to say it again. <i>(1897,Southern Parables,44</i>) [NOTES: (`Arlinton')]

>  Dummy, n. in the early days of settlement, a person who put in a claim for land for the use ofanother. <i>(1929,Whitcombe's Etym. Dict. Aust-NZ Suppl.,4</i>)

>  Dummy: A man who takes a run in his name for the benefit of another; hence to dummy and dummyism. ([1898 Morris Austral-English]) <i>(Oct 14, 1933,Press, The,15</i>) [NOTES: (Acland Gloss.)]

>  Dummy. 5. In Australia and New Zealand, a man who selects land on behalf of another. <i>(1958,Whitcombe's Modern Junior Dictionary (8th edn),133,8th ed.</i>)

>  dummy n. third person or medium at a sale of Crown land, who, swearing he is selecting land for himself, buys it, and, when the deal is completed drops out, allowing the second party to aquire the land for a fee. <i>(1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),8</i>)

>  <b>McCASKILL</b> It would appear that a syndicate of directors and senior officials of the Farmers' Coop Association were the prime movers in the purchase [in 1917] and that the Lockheads were [114] really `dummies' whose initial contributions towards the purchase [of the station] were soon lost. <i>(1969,Molesworth,113</i>)



 
 <i>n.</i> (Rural) a dog-training device consisting of a sheepskin draped over a wire netting frame on a pulley line.

>  <b>WHYTE</b> a dummy is a sheepskin draped over a wire netting frame on a pulley line. <i>(1927,Sheep-Dog, The,13</i>)

 <i>n.</i> (Rural) a partition separating two cows in the double bail of a milking shed.

>  A modification of the dummy and race has come into favour in certain districts during recent years. <i>(Jun 15, 1939,NZ Journal of Agriculture,489</i>)

>  I recall the early sheds with only head bales [sic] and the walk-through with the dummy bale [sic] between cows. [dummy bail] <i>(Aug 10, 1999,Taranaki Daily News,Supp 14</i>)



 
 <i>v.</i> to select Crown land as a dummy. [Hist.]

>  <b>REEVES</b> The attempts often ingeniously made to evade these [land] restrictions by getting the land in the name of relatives, servants, or agents are called `dummyism', and may be punished by imprisonment - never inflicted - by fines, and by forfeiture of the land `dummied.' <i>(1898,Long White Cloud, The,356</i>)

>  Dummy: A man who takes a run in his name for the benefit of another; hence to dummy and dummyism. ([1898 Morris Austral-English]) <i>(Oct 14, 1933,Press, The,15</i>) [NOTES: (Acland Gloss.)]



 
 <i>n.</i>

>  <b>378/3</b> The use of galvanised iron piping or iron piping for erection of internal dummies and partitions. <i>(Apr 1950,NZ Journal of Agriculture</i>)

>  (caption) A small dairy with suspended dummy and bucket milking machine for one cow. <i>(May 1950,NZ Journal of Agriculture,479</i>)



 
 <i>n.</i> fishing rig [(?game fishermen's)]

>  <b>GREY</b> The place looked fishy, and here the boatmen began trolling with hand-lines for bait. They used a small gig, dark in color, shaped like a canoe, which they called a dummy. I rigged up a light tackle and put over a spoon, ... <i>(1926,Angler's Eldorado,33</i>)



 
<b>1</b> <i>v.</i> (Rural) to purchase land in name only for another to use, in order that a holding can be legally extended.

## dunite
 
 <i>n.</i> a mineral from Mt Dun in Nelson; a NZ mineral, a kind of olivine [See cit. 1883. [chk Hochstetter] (geologists' ca1946 p.c. Prof. R. Clarke (Victoria University) Probably the most well-known of NZ-named minerals.']

>  <b>HOCHSTETTER</b> [Dun Mountain, Nelson] consists of a very peculiar kind of rock, of a yellowish-green colour when recently broken, but turning rusty-brown on the surface when decomposing. The mass of the rock is olivine ...; it is distinguished from serpentine for which it was formerly taken, especially by its greater hardness, and its crystalline structure. I have called it Dunite. <i>(1867,New Zealand (Hochstetter),474</i>)

>  <b>HECTOR</b> Chrome ore. This ore, which is a mixture of chromic iron and alumina, is chiefly associated with magnesian rock, resembling olivine in composition, named Dunite by Dr. Hochstetter.' <i>(1883,Handbook of New Zealand,56</i>)

>  This mineral is a massive variety of olivine through which grains of chromite are scattered. A specimen from the Dun Mountain, Nelson, was first described by Dr V. Hochstetter (New Zealand), 1863, Eng ed, p475) ... <i>(1883,TrNZI,15/392</i>) [NOTES: (S.H. Cox)]

>  <b>MORRIS</b> Dunite ... an ore in New Zealand, so called from Dun mountain, near Nelson. <i>(1898,Austral English,132</i>)

>  The less important [is] ... near the celebrated Milford Sound, in Fiordland. This locality is remarkable owing to the presence with the platinum of that peculiar nickel-iron mineral awaruite. In appearance it is not unlike platinum, and was mistaken by the miners for that mineral. ... Both the metal and the awaruite occur in a district composed ... of serpentine and dunite. <i>(1911,TrNZI,43/451</i>)

>  <b>McLINTOCK</b> His [Dr. Ferdinand R. Von Hockstetter's] name `dunite' for the olivine rock of Dun Mountain is firmly established. <i>(1966,Encyclopaedia of New Zealand, An,2/92</i>)

>  dunite n. N.Z. iron ore. [from Dun Mountains, near Nelson N.Z.]. <i>(1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),8</i>)

>  A large Sydney firm is at present interesting itself in the deposits of dunite, a mineral containing copper, on Dun Mountain in the Nelson district. <i>(May 19, 1939,Taranaki Herald,4</i>)

>  <b>CHAPPLE</b> Above Nelson in 1851 the Austrian geologist Ferdinand Hochstetter held a piece of heavy red rock in his hand and named it dunite. <i>(2002,Te Araroa: the New Zealand Trail,1,71 ed.</i>)

>  They described their finds and gave them names based on the local geography - dunite from Dun Mountain, and the semi-precious Rodingite from the Roding River. <i>(1990,Tramping in South Island Forest Parks,16</i>)

## dust
 
 <i>n.</i> the dust, miners' phthisis or silicosis.

>  <b>McARA</b> Dust: Quartz dust was a major menace to the health of miners. It blocked up the microscopic air-sacs in the lungs, producing hardening of the tissues and impairing the function of the lungs. Eventually, sometimes after many years, death resulted. The disease miners' phthisis was commonly called `the dust.' It gradually came to an end after the indroduction of axial-water-feed drills. <i>(1978,Gold Mining at Waihi (Glossary),320</i>)



 
 <i>n.</i> gunpowder [(whalers' ?technical jargon)]

>  <b>WAKEFIELD</b> Dust `gunpowder' <i>(1845,Adventure in NZ,1/318</i>)



 
<b>2</b> <i>n.</i> gold-dust

>  The gold is in dust and nuggets. ... The implement most effectual in economising labour is the `Long Tom', or trough strainer, cradles are but of little comparative service. <i>(Dec 10, 1852,NZ Government Gazette,V/30/183</i>) [NOTES: (Heaphy's Report)]

>  <b>SWAINSON</b> The dust consisted of flaky gold, of a pale lemon colour, largely intermixed with auriferous quartz, the separation having been effected only by washing in the simplest manner. <i>Ibid.</i> 109 These parties also brought up from the same spot various other specimens; one parcel of which, consisting of large rich dust and flakes, and exceedingly auriferous quartz (perhaps as rich, gaudy specimens as have yet been seen), was sold by auction by the undersigned yesterday. <i>(1853,Auckland,106</i>) [NOTES: 1852 Dec 13 Gold Circular in 1853 Swainson Auckland 106]

>  <b>HYDE</b> Hadn't so much as a pick, he hadn't, and when he came down again he was carrying his dust in a sugar-sack on his back. <i>(1938,Nor the Years Condemn,54</i>)



 
<b>3</b> <i>n.</i> a kauri-gum grade, gum-dust

>  The chief factor influencing sales and prices of kauri-gum in recent years has been the rquest for the poorer qualities, called `chips' and `dust'. <i>(Aug 1916,Chambers Edinburgh Journal,542/1</i>) [NOTES: [OED2 chip]]

>  <b>STALLWORTHY</b> At one time the dust, and scrapings, of the gum were not saleable ... Since then there has always been a price of some sort for all dust and scrapings. <i>(1916,Early Northern Wairoa,54</i>)

>  ... it is no doubt also responsible for the dark coloured varnishes produced from the chip grades. [fn] The terms dust, seeds, chips, nubs, &c., are the names given to certain of the lower kauri gum grades according to the relative sizes of the pieces. From `dust' the size of the fragments increases in the order given, as does also the purity of the grade. Chalk, or `chalky gum,' is a particular grade recovered from swampy country and is characterized by its white or chalky appearance and large water content. <i>(1936,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,17/371</i>)

>  <b>McLINTOCK</b> An increasing demand for poorer grades of gum [after 1900], used in making linoleum, made it profitable to search for smaller gum: `nuts', `chips', `seeds', and `dust'. <i>(1966,Encyclopaedia of New Zealand, An,2/207</i>)

>  <b>REED</b> The [1920 Kauri Gum Industry] report stated that during the preceding few years the proportion of low-grade gum, chips and dust (scrapings) had increased in volume ... to about two-thirds of the total gum exports. <i>(1972,Gumdiggers, The,82</i>)

>  <b>MALCOLM</b> The scrapings [sc. of gum] were kept and sold as 'dust', the bigger pieces were known as 'nuts' and the biggest as 'bold'. <i>(1982,Where it all Began,110</i>)

>  In order of decreasing size, the pieces of gum were known as nuggets, nubs, peas, chips, and dust. <i>(Apr 1991,NZ Geographic,41</i>) [NOTES: check whether "nuts" or "nubs"]

>  A corrupt man can sit on a dike and watch [27] a tree beginning to blossom in the yard ... <i>(1972,Islands,1/26</i>) [NOTES: Baxter (Elegy for Boyle Crescent)]
